connected_components.component_name: External Sensor or Analog Signal Source
connected_components.connection_details: The analog output of the sensor or signal source should be connected to the ADC0 pin.
connected_components.purpose: To provide an analog voltage signal for the module to convert into a digital value.

connected_components.connection_details: If the analog input is not in use, the ADC0 pin can be connected to ground.
connected_components.purpose: To ensure a defined low state for the analog input when not in use.

implementation.connectivity: The ADC0 pin should be connected to the analog output of an external sensor or an analog signal source. It should also be connected to ground if the analog input is not being used, or left open if not needed. The pin is an analog input to the module.
implementation.detailed_description: ADC0 is an analog-to-digital converter input pin on the Semtech RC76xx module. It is used to convert analog signals into digital values that can be processed by the module's internal circuitry. The ADC allows the module to interface with external analog sensors or components that generate analog voltage signals.
implementation.functionality: The pin serves as an analog input for the Analog to Digital Converter. It is used to measure external analog voltages, which can then be converted into digital values by the module. This functionality is essential for integrating analog sensors or other analog signal sources with the RC76xx module.
implementation.precautions: The full-scale voltage level for ADC0 is between 0.1V and 1.7V. Applying voltages outside this range may damage the module. Ensure that the signal source is properly interfaced with the module's voltage levels. Additionally, it is recommended to leave the pin open if it is not being used to avoid any potential interference or unintended behavior.

connected_components.description: This is the external source that provides the analog voltage to be measured. This could be a sensor, a voltage divider, or any other analog signal generator.
A resistor can be used in series with the analog signal source for current limiting or signal conditioning if necessary, although not strictly required by the datasheet.
A small capacitor (e.g., 0.1 uF) can be placed in parallel with the ADC1 pin to ground for noise filtering, as is common practice for analog inputs.

implementation.connectivity: The ADC1 pin should be connected to an analog signal source that needs to be measured by the module.  It can be left open or connected to ground if not used.
implementation.detailed_description: The ADC1 pin is an analog input pin for the Analog to Digital Converter (ADC) interface on the Semtech RC76xx module. The module provides two general purpose ADC inputs, ADC1 and ADC0.
implementation.functionality: This pin is dedicated to analog-to-digital conversion. It takes an analog voltage input and converts it into a digital value that can be read by the module's processing core.
precautions: The analog input voltage to ADC1 must remain within the specified full-scale range of 0.1V to 1.7V. Exceeding this range can lead to inaccurate readings or potential damage.
The ADC1 pin should not be connected to any digital signals or power supply rails.

If the pin is not used, it is recommended to leave it open or connect it to ground to avoid floating input issues. However, if connected to ground, ensure it does not interfere with other ground connections.
Ensure proper PCB layout practices are followed to minimize noise coupling to the ADC1 pin, as this can affect the accuracy of the analog-to-digital conversion.

implementation.connected_components: The primary component to be connected to ANT_CNTL0 is the control input of a tunable antenna or an associated switching component. The specific type of component depends on the antenna design. The exact implementation details will be specific to the tunable antenna system being integrated.
implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to the control input of an external tunable antenna system or switch. If not used, it should be left unconnected.
implementation.detailed_description: ANT_CNTL0 is an output signal provided by the Semtech RC76xx module that can be used for host designs incorporating tunable antennas. Specifically, it can be used for customer-defined external switch control for tunable antennas.
implementation.functionality: This pin can be configured for use as a GPIO using the AT+WIOCFG command. It is also used in conjunction with other ANT_CNTL pins (ANT_CNTL1, ANT_CNTL2, ANT_CNTL3) and AT commands like AT!CUSTOM="BANDSELEN",1 and AT!ANTSEL=<band>,<gpio1>,<gpio2>,<gpio3>[,<gpio4>] to tune antennas for specific bands.
implementation.precautions: Host support for antenna control signals is optional. The timing of these signals is not guaranteed by Semtech. Developers should verify the performance of tunable antennas using these signals. If the pin is not used, it should be left unconnected.

connected_components.details: This is an external component or circuit integrated into the host device's antenna system. It receives control signals from the RC76xx module (specifically ANT_CNTL0, ANT_CNTL1, ANT_CNTL2, ANT_CNTL3) to adjust the antenna's operating parameters, such as frequency range or impedance matching. The specific type of switching circuit will depend on the antenna design, but it typically involves an electronic switch (e.g., PIN diodes, FETs) controlled by digital signals.

implementation.connectivity: The ANT_CNTL1 pin should be connected to the control input of an external tunable antenna's switching circuit. This connection allows the RC76xx module to actively manage the antenna's configuration.
implementation.detailed_description: ANT_CNTL1 is an output signal provided by the Semtech RC76xx module that can be used for host designs incorporating tunable antennas. Its specific purpose is to control external switching mechanisms for these tunable antennas.
implementation.functionality: The ANT_CNTL1 pin serves as a control signal for external tunable antennas. Its functionality is primarily to enable antenna tuning, which is often necessary for specific band operations or to optimize performance based on network conditions. The specific behavior of this pin (e.g., whether it's actively driven or can be reconfigured) is dependent on the firmware configuration and AT commands used to manage antenna settings.
precautions: The support for antenna control signals is optional and may be firmware-dependent. Ensure that the specific firmware version loaded onto the module supports the use of these pins for antenna control.
If the ANT_CNTL1 pin is not used, it should be left unconnected ('Leave open') to ensure compatibility with other Semtech CF3 modules and to prevent potential issues.
The AT command AT!CUSTOM="BANDSELEN",1 must be enabled for band selection to be active, which is required for tuning the antennas. This setting is persistent unless explicitly disabled.

The specific mapping of ANT_CNTL signals to antenna tuning parameters is configured via the AT!ANTSEL command, which takes parameters corresponding to <band>, <gpio1>, <gpio2>, <gpio3>, and optionally <gpio4>. Ensure correct configuration to utilize ANT_CNTL1 for the intended tuning function.

implementation.connected_components: The ANT_CNTL2 pin is typically connected to the control input of an external antenna tuner or a switching component within the antenna system. The specific component would be an electronic switch or a digital potentiometer designed to adjust the antenna's characteristics based on control signals. If used as a GPIO, it would connect to the input of a microcontroller or another digital logic input.
implementation.connectivity: ANT_CNTL2 should be connected to the control input of a tunable antenna's switching circuitry or to a GPIO input of another device if used as a GPIO. The signal is an output from the module.
implementation.detailed_description: ANT_CNTL2 is an output signal provided by the Semtech RC76xx module. It is part of a set of four such signals (ANT_CNTL0, ANT_CNTL1, ANT_CNTL2, ANT_CNTL3) intended for host designs that incorporate tunable antennas. These signals can be used to control the antenna's tuning for specific bands, assisting with features like neighbor cell measurements and inter-RAT handovers. The module's support for these antenna control signals is optional.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of ANT_CNTL2 is to act as a customer-defined external switch control for tunable antennas. Its specific behavior (high or low state) is determined by the band the module is operating on, configured via AT commands. It can also be configured for use as a General Purpose Input/Output (GPIO) using the AT+WIOCFG command.
implementation.precautions: The timing of the ANT_CNTL2 signal is not guaranteed by Semtech; developers must evaluate its performance in their specific application. Support for these signals is optional, meaning not all module variants may implement them. If the AT+WIOCFG command is used to configure this pin as a GPIO, it will no longer function as an antenna control signal. Developers should consult the RC76xx AT Command Reference for specific commands related to antenna control and GPIO configuration.

connected_components.component_description: An external tunable antenna that requires control signals for adjusting its operating characteristics. The specific implementation will depend on the antenna's design and the desired tuning parameters.
Other external components or systems that can be controlled by a digital output signal from the module.

implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to the control input of an external tunable antenna system or other external circuitry as determined by the antenna manufacturer's recommendations or specific application requirements.
implementation.detailed_description: ANT_CNTL3 is an output signal from the Semtech RC76xx module that can be used for controlling tunable antennas.
implementation.functionality: This pin can be configured for use as a GPIO using the AT+WIOCFG command. When used for antenna control, it supports the AT!ANTSEL command to tune the antenna for specific bands by driving the signal high or low.
precautions: Antenna control signals support is optional and depends on firmware configuration.
When used for antenna control, the pin's functionality is determined by AT commands, specifically AT!ANTSEL.
Developers are responsible for evaluating the performance of tunable antennas that use these signals.
Semtech does not guarantee the timing of the ANT_CNTLx signals.
If the pin is not used for antenna control or as a GPIO, it should be left unconnected ('Leave open').
Ensure that the pin is not driven to a logic high level if it's intended to be used for other control purposes where a low level is active.

connected_components.connection_description: The DR_SYNC output from the module should be connected to a corresponding input or synchronization logic on the host device. This connection allows the host to utilize the precise timing information provided by the GPS for dead reckoning calculations.

implementation.connectivity: The DR_SYNC signal is an output from the module. It should be connected to a host device that requires GPS synchronization signals for dead reckoning functionality.
implementation.detailed_description: The DR_SYNC pin is an output signal used for GPS dead reckoning synchronization. The module pulses this signal once every integer GPS second. When position fixes are occurring, the DR_SYNC pulse is aligned precisely with the GPS time. When a position fix cannot be made (e.g., in a tunnel), the module continues to pulse the DR_SYNC signal every second as long as the uncertainty of the GPS time is low. When the uncertainty level becomes high, the module stops pulsing the signal.
implementation.functionality: The pin functions as a GPS dead reckoning synchronization signal. It pulses once every GPS second, aligned with GPS time when fixes are available. When fixes are not available but GPS time uncertainty is low, it continues to pulse. If GPS time uncertainty is high, the pulsing stops.
precautions: The pin has an internal pull-down when the module boots or resets.

The DR_SYNC signal's availability and stability are dependent on the GPS receiver's ability to acquire and maintain a position fix. In environments with poor GPS reception, the signal may become unstable or cease altogether.
The host device should be designed to handle potential variations or absence of the DR_SYNC signal if operating in GPS-denied environments.

connected_components.connection_details: The EXT_GPS_LNA_EN pin should be connected to the enable/control pin of the external GNSS LNA. The specific pin will vary depending on the LNA component chosen.

implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to the enable or control input of an external GNSS LNA component. The signal should be routed to the appropriate pin on the LNA that activates its amplification circuitry.
implementation.detailed_description: EXT_GPS_LNA_EN is an output signal from the Semtech RC76xx module that controls an external Low Noise Amplifier (LNA) for the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receiver. When the GNSS functionality is active and requires the external LNA to be enabled, this pin will drive high. This allows the host device to manage the power to the external LNA, optimizing power consumption when GNSS is not in use.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of EXT_GPS_LNA_EN is to enable or disable an external GNSS LNA. It drives high when the GNSS receiver is active and requires amplification. It is typically driven low or left open when GNSS is inactive, thus powering down the external LNA.
precautions: Ensure the external LNA is compatible with the 1.8V logic level output of the EXT_GPS_LNA_EN pin.
If the external LNA is not used, this pin should be left unconnected (open).
The default state of the pin when the module boots or resets is 'H' (High), indicating the LNA is enabled by default. This behavior may need to be managed in the host application's power sequencing.
Verify that the chosen external LNA does not draw excessive current when enabled by this signal, as it is an output pin with limited current drive capability.

connected_components.description: A component that allows selection between multiple SIM cards, controlled by the Ext_SIM_switch pin. Examples include FSA2567MPX.
For GPIO functionality, it connects to external components as per the application's needs.
For RESET_OUT_N functionality, it connects to the reset input of peripheral devices.

implementation.connectivity: When used for SIM switching, it connects to the control input of an external SIM switch IC. When configured as a GPIO, it connects to external circuitry as a digital input/output. When used as RESET_OUT_N, it connects to the reset input of peripheral devices.
implementation.detailed_description: The Ext_SIM_switch pin is an output signal from the Semtech RC76xx module that is used to control an external SIM switch. This allows the module to select between two external SIM cards (UIM1_SIMA and UIM1_SIMB). The pin's functionality is managed by AT commands, specifically AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",1 to enable the feature, and then AT!ANTSEL=<band>,<gpio1>,<gpio2>,<gpio3>[,<gpio4>] to control the SIM selection based on the band.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as an output to control an external SIM switch. It can also be configured as a general purpose Input/Output (GPIO) pin when the external SIM switch functionality is disabled. Additionally, it can function as a RESET_OUT_N signal, providing a reset signal to peripheral devices.
implementation.precautions: When configured for SIM switching, ensure the AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",1 command is used to enable the feature. When used as a GPIO or RESET_OUT_N, the SIM switching feature must be disabled using AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",0. Always refer to the AT command reference for specific configuration details and potential interactions with other pin functions.

connected_components.component_description: The ground plane of the application board. This should be a solid, continuous plane under the module, with numerous via connections to other ground layers to ensure low impedance and good thermal conductivity.

implementation.connectivity: All GND pins on the module must be connected to the ground plane of the host PCB. The datasheet recommends using a solid ground plane under the module and employing a high density of vias to connect this plane to other ground layers of the PCB. This ensures a robust ground connection and facilitates heat dissipation.
implementation.detailed_description: Ground is a common reference point for all electrical signals and power supply rails within the module. It is essential for signal integrity, proper operation of internal circuitry, and thermal dissipation. The module utilizes multiple GND pins to ensure robust grounding connections and to facilitate efficient heat transfer from the module to the host PCB. These pins are connected to the internal ground plane of the module, which is internally connected to the shield.
implementation.functionality: The GND pins primarily serve as the electrical ground reference for the module. They are also critical for establishing a low-impedance return path for RF signals, power supply currents, and high-speed digital signals. Additionally, the extensive ground connections contribute to the module's thermal management by acting as a heat sink to the host PCB.
precautions: Ensure all GND pins are securely connected to the host PCB's ground plane. Inadequate grounding can lead to signal integrity issues, noise, and unreliable operation.
Do not use GND pins for any signal routing. They are strictly for ground connections.
When routing RF traces (RF_MAIN, RF_DIV, RF_GNSS), the associated GND pads should be considered an integral part of the RF interface. Ensure proper ground plane coverage around these pads.
The ground plane connection is crucial for thermal dissipation. Ensure the thermal path from the module's GND pads to the host PCB's thermal management system is efficient.

connected_components.connection_details: Connected to pin 44 (GPIO13) of the Semtech RC76xx module.

implementation.connectivity: GPIO13 should be connected as a General Purpose Input/Output. If unused, it should be left open.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO13 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin. It is part of the Extension functionality group, meaning it provides additional capabilities beyond the core functions and its availability and location may vary across different Semtech CF3 modules. The pin is configured as a digital I/O with a pull-down resistor by default in its active state.
implementation.functionality: GPIO13 can serve as a General Purpose Input/Output pin. Its specific behavior, such as being a wakeable pin, is indicated as 'Yes' in the pin definition table, meaning it can be used to trigger the module to wake up from sleep mode. The default state is Pull Down (PD).
precautions: The pin is marked as 'wakeable', so care should be taken if it is used as a standard GPIO to avoid unintentional wake-ups from sleep mode.
As with other GPIO pins, there should not be any voltage applied to GPIO13 when the module is off or resetting.

implementation.connected_components: Host microcontroller's GPIO pins.
implementation.connectivity: When used as a general-purpose I/O, it is connected to the host microcontroller's GPIO. When used as a wakeup source, it is connected to a host signal that can transition to wake the device. The pin has an internal pull-down resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO2 is a general-purpose input/output pin that can be configured by the user. It is also capable of waking the device from a sleep state.
implementation.functionality: GPIO2 can function as a general-purpose input or output. It can also serve as a wakeup source when the device is in a sleep state.
implementation.precautions: The pin has an internal pull-down resistor. When the module is off or resetting, no voltage should be applied to the GPIOs. The pin is 'wakeable' and can be used to trigger the module to wake up from sleep mode.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect to a digital I/O pin on the host microcontroller for general purpose input/output functionality. If used for wake-up, connect to a GPIO output pin on the host.

An internal pull-down resistor is present, so an external pull-down is generally not required. However, if specific pull-up behavior is needed for wake-up functionality, an external pull-up resistor may be considered as per the module's documentation for wakeable pins.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, GPIO21 can be connected as a general-purpose digital input or output to the host system. If used as a wake-up source from Sleep state, it should be connected to a host control signal. The pin has an internal pull-down resistor in its default/active state.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO21 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin that can be used by the host to control or monitor various functions. It is also designated as a wakeable pin, meaning it can be used to wake the module from a Sleep state. The specific behavior and configuration of GPIO21 can be managed through AT commands.
implementation.functionality: Yes, GPIO21 can serve different functions based on its configuration and the module's state. Primarily, it functions as a General Purpose Input/Output (GPIO). Additionally, it can act as a wakeable pin, allowing the host to wake the module from a Sleep state. The default state when the module is in active or sleep mode is a pull-down.
precautions: The pin is 'wakeable', meaning transitions on this pin can wake the module from Sleep state. Ensure proper signal design to avoid unintended wake-ups.
When the module is in PSM (Power Saving Mode), this pin is not a supported wake-up source.
Avoid applying any voltage to the GPIOs when the module is off or resetting.
The pin has an internal pull-down resistor in its default/active state. If connecting to a host output, ensure compatibility with this configuration.

implementation.connected_components: No specific components are mandated for connection by default. Its connection depends on the intended use case, whether it's for controlling an external device (output) or receiving an input/wake signal.
implementation.connectivity: For general purpose use, it can be left unconnected if unused. If used as a wakeable input, it would be connected to a signal source that can assert the wake-up trigger. If configured as an output, it would be connected to the component that needs to be controlled by this GPIO.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO22 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin. It is part of the core functions and is available across various RC76xx modules.
implementation.functionality: This pin can serve as a General Purpose Input/Output. Its default state when unused is 'leave open'. It is also marked as 'wakeable', meaning it can be used to trigger the module to wake up from a sleep state.
implementation.precautions: When the module is in sleep mode, this pin can be used to wake it up. If the module is in PSM mode, this pin is not a valid wakeup source. Ensure proper configuration using AT commands if specific behavior (like wake-up) is required.

implementation.connected_components: No specific external components are mandated for basic connectivity. However, depending on its configured function (input or output), it may connect to other digital components in the system (e.g., buttons, LEDs, other ICs).
implementation.connectivity: It can be connected as a digital input or output. The default state is Pull Down (PD) in active status. If unused, it should be left open.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO23 is a General Purpose Input Output pin that can be configured by the user. It is part of the Extension group of pins.
implementation.functionality: This pin can serve as a General Purpose Input Output. Its specific functionality is determined by user configuration via AT commands.
implementation.precautions: The pin is listed as 'Reserved' in some contexts within the document (though its pin number 149 is allocated). Users should ensure its intended use is supported by their specific module variant and firmware. It is generally advised not to apply voltage to GPIOs when the module is off or resetting.

implementation.connected_components: No specific external components are mandated for connection to GPIO24 if it is to be used as a general-purpose I/O. However, its functionality might be influenced by other system components through software configuration.
implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, GPIO24 can be connected as a digital input or output depending on its configuration. If unused, it should be left open according to the pin definition table.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO24 is a general-purpose input/output pin that can be configured by the user for various functionalities. It is part of the general-purpose input/output pins available on the Semtech RC76xx module.
implementation.functionality: Yes, GPIO24 can serve different functions based on connectivity and configuration. Its primary function is as a general-purpose input/output. It is also listed as an 'Extension' type pin, indicating it may have additional capabilities or specific configurations available through AT commands.
implementation.precautions: The pin has a default pull-down (PD) state in active mode. If the pin is to be used as an input, ensure the signal level is properly driven. If it's used as an output, ensure the connected circuitry respects the voltage and current capabilities. If left unused, it should be left open to ensure compatibility with other Semtech CF3 modules.

implementation.connected_components: No specific components are mandated for connection, but it can interface with microcontrollers, sensors, or other digital components as a general-purpose I/O. If unused, it should not be connected to any component.
implementation.connectivity: Connect to a host microcontroller's GPIO pin or other digital logic. If unused, it should be left open.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO25 is a general-purpose input/output pin, configurable by the user.
implementation.functionality: This pin can be configured as a general-purpose input or output.
implementation.precautions: Pull-up/pull-down resistors may be needed depending on the configuration and the specific application. Refer to the datasheet for specific electrical characteristics and default states.

implementation.connected_components: When used for antenna control, GPIO28 connects to components that manage tunable antennas.  When used as a general purpose I/O, it connects to other digital components in the system as required by the application.
implementation.connectivity: GPIO28 can be connected as a general purpose input or output.  It can also be connected to control signals for tunable antennas (ANT_CNTL1).
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO28 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin that can be configured and utilized for various custom functions as defined by the user.
implementation.functionality: Yes, GPIO28 can serve different functions. It can be configured as a general purpose input/output pin or used for specific antenna control functions. The specific functionality is determined by the user through AT commands like AT+WIOCFG and AT!ANTSEL.
implementation.precautions: GPIO28 should only be used when configured via AT commands.  Ensure proper configuration to avoid unintended behavior.  When used as an output, ensure the voltage and current ratings are not exceeded.  If the module is powered off or resetting, no voltage should be applied to this pin.

implementation.connected_components: When used as a GPIO, it can be connected to microcontrollers, sensors, or other digital components. When used for Antenna Control, it connects to antenna tuning circuitry, which may involve variable capacitors or other RF components. The specific components depend on the antenna design.
implementation.connectivity: If used as a GPIO, it should be connected to other digital logic components as per the desired application. If used for Antenna Control, it connects to the antenna tuning circuitry.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO29 is a general-purpose input/output pin that can be configured for various functions through AT commands.
implementation.functionality: This pin can serve as a General Purpose Input/Output (GPIO) or as an Antenna Control signal (ANT_CNTL1).
implementation.precautions: The pin's function is configurable via AT commands (`AT+WIOCFG`). When not used, it should be left unconnected. If used as a GPIO, ensure proper voltage level compatibility (1.8V). When configured as a GPIO, it is pulled down by default.

connected_components.connection_details: If used for antenna control, it connects to an antenna tuner circuit to adjust antenna characteristics based on the RF band being used.
If used as a GPIO, it connects to the host controller for general purpose input/output operations.

implementation.connectivity: The pin can be configured as a GPIO or as an antenna control signal. If configured as a GPIO, it is a general-purpose input/output with a pull-down resistor. If configured for antenna control, it is used to control tunable antennas.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO30 is a general-purpose input/output pin.
precautions: When configured as a GPIO, the pin should not be left floating if not used. It is recommended to connect it to a pull-down resistor.
When configured for antenna control, ensure the correct AT commands are used to set the antenna control mode and the associated GPIO signals.
Ensure proper routing of the pin to avoid interference with RF signals.
The default state of the pin is a pull-down when used as a GPIO.

implementation.connected_components: If used as a general-purpose I/O, it can connect to microcontrollers, sensors, or other digital logic ICs. If used for antenna control, it connects to the control pin of a tunable antenna module or circuit.
implementation.connectivity: The pin can be left open if not used. If used as a general-purpose I/O, it can be connected to other digital components as an input or output. If used for antenna control, it connects to the control input of an external tunable antenna component. When used as a general-purpose I/O, it has a pull-down resistor enabled by default in active status.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO31 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin, meaning it can be configured by the user to serve as either an input or an output for various digital signals. Its default state in an active system is a pull-down configuration, making it an input by default unless actively changed by software.
implementation.functionality: Yes, GPIO31 can serve different functions based on connectivity. It can be used as a general-purpose input/output pin, and also as an antenna control signal (ANT_CNTL3). The specific function is determined by software configuration, typically through AT commands like AT+WIOCFG for general I/O or AT!CUSTOM and AT!ANTSEL for antenna control.
implementation.precautions: When used as a general-purpose I/O, it should be configured using AT+WIOCFG. When used for antenna control, the ANT_CNTL configuration commands (AT!CUSTOM and AT!ANTSEL) must be used. Ensure that the pin is not connected to any signal that would violate its voltage or current ratings. It is also important to note that the 'Reserved' status of certain pins means they should not be connected to ensure compatibility.

connected_components.connection_details: Can be connected to microcontrollers, sensors, or other digital logic for control or status reporting. Requires consideration of voltage levels (1.8V) and pull-up/pull-down configurations.

Internal pull-down resistors are present. External pull-up or pull-down resistors may be needed depending on the application's specific requirements and the desired default state, as per AT command configuration.

implementation.connectivity: This pin can be configured as a general-purpose input or output. When used as an input, it can receive signals from external components. When used as an output, it can drive external components. The specific configuration (input or output, pull-up/pull-down) is determined by AT commands.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO32 is a general-purpose input/output pin, part of the module's interface for external connectivity and control.
precautions: Ensure that the voltage level of any connected external component does not exceed the 1.8V operating voltage of the GPIO.
When the module is in Sleep or Off mode, external signals applied to this pin might affect power consumption or behavior. Refer to the documentation for specific behavior in different power states.
The default state of the pin is a pull-down. If a different default behavior is required, it must be configured via AT commands.
Avoid applying voltages to this pin when the module is powered off or in reset state to prevent potential damage.

connected_components.description: Connect to a general-purpose input/output pin on the host microcontroller or processor.
An internal pull-down resistor is present and enabled by default in the active state. This ensures a defined low logic level when the pin is not actively driven.

If used as a wake-up source, external circuitry (e.g., a switch or signal conditioning) may be needed to properly trigger the wake-up event, depending on the host's signal levels and the module's wake-up requirements.

implementation.connectivity: The pin should be connected to the host system's GPIO interface. If unused, it should be left open. If used as a wake-up source, appropriate external circuitry might be required depending on the host's implementation.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO33 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin. It can be configured by the user to perform various input or output functions based on the application's needs. The default state is an input with a pull-down resistor enabled.
implementation.functionality: This pin can be configured as a General Purpose Input/Output. It can be used for various custom functions as determined by the application. Additionally, it can be wakeable, meaning it can trigger the module to wake up from a sleep state.
precautions: The pin is wakeable from Sleep state. Ensure this is accounted for in system power management design.
If unused, the pin should be left open. Avoid connecting it to any signal or voltage source unless explicitly configured for a specific function.

When the module is in PSM or Off mode, the VGPIO (which powers this pin) is off. Ensure that any external circuitry connected to this pin does not cause unintended power draw or signal integrity issues when the module is in these low-power states.

The default state for this pin when the module is active is input with a pull-down resistor. If the pin is to be used as an output or a different input configuration, it must be explicitly configured via AT commands (e.g., AT+WIOCFG).

implementation.connected_components: If used as a general-purpose output, GPIO35 might be connected to components such as LEDs (potentially with a current-limiting resistor), transistors (for switching higher voltage/current loads), or directly to other digital input pins of microcontrollers or integrated circuits. If used as an input, it would connect to the output of a sensor or another digital signal source.
implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, GPIO35 can be connected as either an input or an output. If used as an input, it would connect to a signal source. If used as an output, it would connect to a device that can be controlled by a digital signal (e.g., an LED, a transistor for switching, etc.). If left unused, it should be left open.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO35 is a general-purpose input/output pin that can be configured by the user. Its default state is a pull-down resistor enabled.
implementation.functionality: This pin is primarily a general-purpose input/output (GPIO). Its specific functionality can be configured by the user through AT commands, allowing it to be used for various purposes depending on the application's needs. However, the datasheet does not specify distinct alternate functions for GPIO35, implying its primary role is as a configurable I/O.
implementation.precautions: When using GPIO35, it's important to note that it has a default pull-down configuration. If the pin is not actively driven or connected, it will be held at a low logic level. Ensure that any external circuitry connected to GPIO35 does not violate the voltage or current specifications for the pin, as detailed in the datasheet's electrical characteristics for GPIOs. Additionally, if the module enters a low-power state (like Sleep or PSM), the behavior of GPIO pins might change, and specific configurations might be required to ensure proper wake-up or signal maintenance.

implementation.connected_components: For SIM Detect functionality, an external pull-up resistor is required. The specific value is not detailed, but it is implied to be necessary for the signal to transition correctly. For general purpose input, the module has an internal pull-down resistor.
implementation.connectivity:
To use GPIO4 for SIM Detect:
- Enable the external SIM detect feature using the AT command AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",1.
- Select the SIM using AT+KSIMSEL=2.
- Reboot the module.

To use GPIO4 as a general purpose input:
- Disable the external SIM detect feature using AT!UNLOCK="A710".
- Configure the UIM2 interface to be disabled using AT+CUSTOM="UIM2ENABLE",0.
- Reboot the module.
- Configure GPIO4 using the AT command AT+WIOCFG=4,4.

For SIM Detect, the signal needs an external pull-up resistor. The UIM detect signal transitions from low to high when a UIM is inserted, and from high to low when removed. The default state of GPIO4 is a digital input with pull-down.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO4 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin. It can be used for two primary functions: SIM Detect for UIM2, or as a general-purpose input/output pin.
implementation.functionality:
GPIO4 can function as:
1. SIM Detect for UIM2: Detects the physical presence of a UIM card in the UIM2 holder.
2. General Purpose Input/Output: Can be configured as a digital input for general use.
implementation.precautions: When using GPIO4 for SIM Detect, ensure the external pull-up resistor is properly implemented. When configuring GPIO4 as a general-purpose input, the external SIM detect feature must be disabled, and the UIM2 interface must be disabled. The default state of GPIO4 is a digital input with a pull-down, and its functionality can be altered via AT commands.

implementation.connected_components: No specific external components are mandated for its basic GPIO function.  However, its wakeable functionality implies it could be connected to a signal from another component that triggers a wake-up event.
implementation.connectivity: As a GPIO, it can be configured as an input or output.  Specific configuration for its wakeable functionality or GPIO behavior is done via AT commands.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO42 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin on the Semtech RC76xx module. It is wakeable, meaning it can be used to wake the module from a sleep state. Its default state is a pull-down.
implementation.functionality: GPIO42 can be used as a General Purpose Input/Output. It is also 'wakeable', allowing it to trigger the module to wake up from a sleep state.
implementation.precautions: The pin is wakeable, so care should be taken with external connections to prevent unintended wake-ups from sleep state.  The default state has an internal pull-down.  For specific configuration and usage details, AT commands such as AT+WIOCFG are referenced.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect to the SIM switch control input. The state of GPIO6 (high or low) will control the switch to select between SIM A and SIM B.
Connect to the reset input of peripheral devices. When configured as RESET_OUT_N, GPIO6 will drive these devices into reset or take them out of reset.
Can be connected as a digital input or output to the host controller for general purpose I/O functionality.

implementation.connectivity: For SIM Switching, enable via AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",1. For General Purpose Input/Output, disable SIM switching via AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",0 and configure GPIO6 using AT+WIOCFG=6,4. For RESET_OUT_N, disable SIM switching via AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",0 and configure GPIO6 using AT+WIOCFG=6,0. The default GPIO state is a digital input with a 10 µA pull-down function. When used as RESET_OUT_N, it is held low to reset peripheral devices during power-up and then turned high once the power-on sequence is complete.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO6 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin that can also be configured to control an external SIM switch or function as a RESET_OUT_N signal.
implementation.functionality: GPIO6 can be used for three different functions: SIM Switching, General Purpose Input/Output, or as a RESET_OUT_N signal.
precautions: The default GPIO state is a digital input with a 10 µA pull-down function.
When configuring GPIO6 for different functions, a reboot of the module may be required.
If used as RESET_OUT_N, it is held low during module reset or power-up and then turned high once the power-on sequence is complete. It maintains its previous state during PSM.
The signal is available for use when configured using AT+WIOCFG. Refer to the RC76xx AT Command Reference for details.

implementation.connected_components: No specific connected components are mandated by the datasheet for GPIO7's general function. Its use as a wake-up source would depend on the host system's design and the specific events it needs to signal. If left unused, it can be left open or connected to ground.
implementation.connectivity: GPIO7 can be connected as a digital input or output. When used as a wake-up source, it should be connected to a signal that can trigger the module from sleep. If unused, it should be left open or connected to ground to maintain its default state.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO7 is a General Purpose Input/Output pin. It is a wakeable pin, meaning it can be used to wake the module from a sleep state. The default state of GPIO7 is configured as an input with a pull-down resistor. It is available for general purpose use.
implementation.functionality: GPIO7 can function as a General Purpose Input/Output pin. It can also act as a wakeable interrupt source, allowing it to wake the module from a sleep state.
implementation.precautions: When the module is in sleep mode, transitions on GPIO7 can wake the module. If the module is in PSM, GPIO7 cannot be used as a wakeup source; only POWER_ON_N and RESET_IN_N are supported. Additionally, no voltage should be applied to the GPIOs when the module is off or resetting.

implementation.connected_components: No specific connected components are mandated by the datasheet. The connection will depend on the specific application's requirement for GPIO8.
implementation.connectivity: When used as a general-purpose input, GPIO8 should be connected to a signal source. When used as a general-purpose output, it can be connected to a load or indicator.  If unused, it should be left open.
implementation.detailed_description: GPIO8 is a general-purpose input/output pin. It can be configured to perform various functions based on the system's needs.  The pin's default state is as a general-purpose input.
implementation.functionality: GPIO8 can function as a general-purpose input or output. Its specific behavior can be configured through software, allowing it to be used for various control or monitoring tasks.
implementation.precautions: As with all GPIO pins, care should be taken to ensure that the voltage levels connected to GPIO8 are within the specified operating voltage range for the module.  Refer to the datasheet for precise voltage specifications.  The datasheet does not specify any special precautions beyond standard GPIO usage.

implementation.connected_components: This pin needs to be connected to the CLK pin of the I2C bus of other devices (e.g., sensors, microcontrollers) that the RC76xx module will communicate with.
implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to the I2C bus clock line. The interface uses 1.8V logic, and the signals are implemented internally as open drain outputs with 2.5 kΩ pull-up resistors to VGPIO.
implementation.detailed_description: I2C1_CLK is the clock signal for the I2C1 interface. The Semtech RC76xx module provides one I2C (Inter-Integrated Circuit) dedicated serial port (bus interface) based on I2C Bus Specification, Version 5.0, October 2012. This interface uses pin 1 for the clock signal and pin 66 for the data signal.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the I2C clock signal. The module operates only in master mode for this interface.
implementation.precautions: The I2C1_CLK pin has internal pull-up resistors. Ensure that when connecting to other I2C devices, the bus is correctly terminated according to I2C standards. Avoid connecting any external pull-up resistors as it may interfere with the internal configuration.

implementation.connectivity: The I2C1_DATA pin should be connected to the corresponding data pin (SDA) of the I2C slave device(s) in the system. It is an open-drain output, meaning it requires external pull-up resistors. These pull-up resistors should be connected to the VGPIO supply. The datasheet recommends internal pull-up resistors with a value of 2.2 kΩ to VGPIO.
implementation.detailed_description: The I2C1_DATA pin is part of the I2C1 interface, which is a dedicated serial port based on the I2C Bus Specification. This interface allows the RC76xx module to communicate with other I2C devices. The module operates as an I2C master, meaning it initiates and controls the communication on the bus.
implementation.functionality: The pin serves as the data line for the I2C communication. It is used for both sending and receiving data between the RC76xx module (as the master) and any connected I2C slave devices. Its functionality is tied to the I2C1_CLK pin.
precautions: The I2C1_DATA pin is open-drain and requires external pull-up resistors to VGPIO.
The recommended value for the pull-up resistor is 2.2 kΩ. The datasheet also mentions internal pull-up resistors, but it's good practice to implement external ones for robust design.
The I2C interface operates at 1.8V, so ensure that connected slave devices are compatible with this voltage level.
An I2C slave address of 0x1A is reserved for internal use by the module. Avoid using this address for any external I2C devices.

Ensure that the total capacitance on the I2C bus (including trace capacitance and slave device capacitance) does not exceed the limits specified by the I2C standard to maintain proper communication speeds.

I2S_CLK.description:
I2S Clock
The frame bit clock signal controls data
transfer with the audio peripheral.

connected_components.connection_details: The I2S_CLK pin of the module connects to the SCK (Serial Clock) pin of the external audio codec. The module acts as the master for the I2S clock. The external codec's SCK input receives the clock signal from the module.

implementation.connectivity: When the digital audio interface is configured for I2S, this pin should be connected to the SCK (Serial Clock) input of the external I2S-compatible audio codec (DAC/ADC).
implementation.detailed_description: The I2S_CLK pin is part of the I2S (Inter-IC Sound) digital audio interface. In this context, it serves as the bit clock signal that controls the data transfer rate between the module and an external stereo DAC/ADC.
implementation.functionality: The pin is configured as an Output when the digital audio interface is set to I2S mode. It provides the I2S clock signal. The functionality of this pin is dependent on the module's audio interface configuration being set to I2S. If the audio interface is configured for PCM, this pin would be PCM_CLK.
precautions: The module acts as the master for the I2S clock, so ensure the external codec is configured to accept the clock from a master source.
The I2S interface supports a sampling rate of 16 kHz and a bit clock of 512 kHz. Ensure the external codec is compatible with these specifications.
The pin is pulled high by default in its reset state when configured for I2S. If the audio interface is configured for PCM, it defaults to a pull-down.
The module's audio availability is firmware-dependent. Ensure the firmware supports I2S audio configuration.

I2S_CLK.name: I2S_CLK

I2S_IN.description:
I2S Data In
The frame “data in” relies on the selected
configuration mode.

connected_components.description: A digital-to-analog converter (DAC) or analog-to-digital converter (ADC) that supports the I2S protocol. This component will provide the digital audio data that is fed into the RC76xx module via the I2S_IN pin.

implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to the corresponding data output pin of an external audio component (e.g., a stereo DAC/ADC) that also supports the I2S protocol. The connection carries the digital audio data stream from the external component to the RC76xx module.
implementation.detailed_description: The I2S_IN pin is part of the I2S (Inter-IC Sound) digital audio interface. It serves as the input for serial digital audio data that is transferred to the Semtech RC76xx module from an external stereo DAC/ADC. The I2S interface allows for the transfer of digital audio information between the module and external audio components.
implementation.functionality: This pin can function as part of the I2S digital audio interface. When the module's audio interface is configured for I2S operation, this pin receives the digital audio data. It is also mentioned that the I2S_OUT pin serves as the I2S Data Out. The pin is also part of the PCM/I2S interface signals, indicating it can be used in either PCM or I2S mode, but for I2S mode, it specifically handles the input data.
precautions: The I2S interface only supports master mode operation, meaning the Semtech RC76xx module controls the clock and word select signals.
The I2S interface only supports a sampling rate of 16 kHz and 16 bits per frame. Ensure the external audio component is configured to match these parameters.
The I2S_IN pin has a default reset state of Pull Down.
If the I2S interface is not used, this pin should be left unconnected (pulled down).
The I2S interface operates at 1.8V logic levels. Ensure the connected external audio component is compatible with this voltage level.

I2S_IN.name: I2S_IN

I2S_OUT.description:
I2S Data Out
The frame “data out” relies on the
selected configuration mode.

implementation.connected_components: The I2S_OUT pin connects to the data input pin of an external audio device, such as a Digital-to-Analog Converter (DAC) or Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) that supports the I2S protocol. This could be a dedicated audio codec chip. The connection would be from I2S_OUT on the module to the data input (e.g., DIN, SDATA) on the audio codec. If configured for PCM, it connects to a PCM input on an audio device.
implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, the I2S_OUT pin should be connected to the data input pin of an external audio codec (DAC/ADC) or other audio processing device that supports the I2S interface. If the PCM interface is used, it connects to the PCM_OUT pin of the module, which would connect to the corresponding PCM input on the external device.
implementation.detailed_description: The I2S_OUT pin is part of the digital audio interface and is used to transmit serial digital audio data from the Semtech RC76xx module to an external stereo DAC/ADC. It is part of the I2S (Inter-IC Sound) interface, which allows for the transfer of digital audio data.
implementation.functionality: The I2S_OUT pin can serve multiple functions depending on the selected audio interface configuration. When the digital audio interface is configured as I2S, this pin functions as the I2S Data Out. If the interface is configured as PCM, this pin is named PCM_OUT and carries PCM data. The function is determined by firmware configuration.
implementation.precautions: The I2S_OUT pin is an output from the module. The module's datasheet specifies that when the I2S interface is used, this pin should be connected to a pull-down resistor if it is unused. The voltage level for this interface is 1.8V. Ensure that the external device connected to I2S_OUT is compatible with I2S protocol and the specified voltage levels. Firmware configuration is required to enable and select the I2S interface.

I2S_OUT.name: I2S_OUT

I2S_WS.description:
I2S Word Select
The word select clock indicates which
channel is currently being transmitted
(low cycle indicates left audio channel,
high cycle indicates right audio channel).

implementation.connected_components: The I2S_WS pin connects to the Word Select (WS) input of the external I2S audio device (e.g., a DAC or ADC).
implementation.connectivity: In I2S mode, I2S_WS is an output from the module. It should be connected to the corresponding WS input of the I2S master device (e.g., an audio codec).
implementation.detailed_description: The I2S_WS (Word Select) signal for the I2S audio interface indicates which audio channel is currently being transmitted or received. Typically, a low cycle indicates the left audio channel, and a high cycle indicates the right audio channel.
implementation.functionality: The I2S_WS signal can serve as a PCM_SYNC signal when the digital audio interface is configured for PCM mode.
implementation.precautions: When the module is in reset or powering up, the I2S_WS pin has a pull-down reset state. Ensure that the connected I2S device handles this state appropriately. If the digital audio interface is not used, this pin should be left open or pulled down.

I2S_WS.name: I2S_WS

PCM_CLK.description:
PCM Clock
The frame bit clock signal controls data
transfer with the audio peripheral.

implementation.connected_components: PCM Clock output from the module connects to the clock input of an audio peripheral (e.g., codec, DSP). The specific peripheral will have a corresponding clock input pin.
implementation.connectivity: In PCM Master mode, this pin should be connected as an output clock signal to the audio peripheral. When used in Primary mode, the connection details are not explicitly defined beyond its Input/Output nature.
implementation.detailed_description: The PCM_CLK pin is part of the 4-wire digital audio interface, which can be configured as either PCM (Pulse Code Modulation) or I2S (Inter-IC Sound). When configured for PCM, it serves as the PCM Clock signal. In Master mode, it acts as an output that controls data transfer with the audio peripheral. In Primary mode, its role is described as 'Input/Output', indicating it might function as both an input and output depending on the specific configuration or context, but its primary role in PCM Master mode is an output clock.
implementation.functionality: PCM Clock (Output in Master mode), Input/Output in Primary mode
implementation.precautions: When the module is in PCM Master mode, this pin is an output. Ensure proper termination or connection to prevent signal integrity issues. The datasheet also specifies that in Primary mode, it is an Input/Output, which might require further clarification depending on the specific implementation or configuration settings related to 'Primary mode'.

PCM_CLK.name: PCM_CLK

PCM_IN.description:
PCM Data In
The frame “data in” relies on the selected
configuration mode.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect the PCM_IN pin of the RC76xx module to the corresponding PCM_IN pin of the audio codec or external audio peripheral. If the interface is configured for I2S, connect to the I2S_IN pin.
The PCM_IN pin (pin 34) on the RC76xx module.

implementation.connectivity: In PCM mode, PCM_IN should be connected to the PCM_IN pin of the audio codec or external audio peripheral. A 'Pull Down' configuration is recommended for the reset state. If the digital audio interface is configured for I2S mode, PCM_IN should be connected to the I2S_IN pin of the audio codec. In this case, a 'Pull Down' is also recommended for the reset state.
implementation.detailed_description: The PCM_IN pin is part of the 4-wire digital audio interface of the Semtech RC76xx module. This interface can be configured as either PCM (Pulse Code Modulation) or I2S (Inter-IC Sound). When configured for PCM, PCM_IN serves as the input for PCM Data. The frame synchronization signal (PCM_SYNC) synchronizes the data in and out of the module. The clock signal (PCM_CLK) controls the data transfer with the audio peripheral. The data format is 16-bit linear, with a specific PDM bit format (S DDD DDDD DDDD DDVV), where S is the signed bit, D is data, and V is volume padding.
implementation.functionality: The PCM_IN pin's primary function is to receive PCM Data when the digital audio interface is configured for PCM mode. If the interface is configured for I2S mode, this pin serves as the I2S_IN pin, receiving I2S Data.
precautions: When the module is in its reset state, it is recommended to have a pull-down configuration on this pin.
Audio availability is firmware-dependent; ensure the firmware supports PCM or I2S audio interface.
If the interface is configured for PCM, a 'Leave open' state is recommended if unused.
If the interface is configured for I2S, a 'Pull Down' state is recommended if unused.

PCM_IN.name: PCM_IN

PCM_OUT.description:
PCM Data Out
The frame “data out” relies on the
selected configuration mode.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect PCM_OUT pin to the data input of the external audio codec/processing unit.
connected_components.description: This is an external chip responsible for converting the digital audio signal from PCM_OUT into an analog signal or further processing the digital audio data. It would have a corresponding data input pin that accepts the PCM_OUT signal.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect PCM_OUT pin (when configured as I2S_OUT) to the I2S data input of the external I2S audio peripheral.
connected_components.description: If the pin is configured as I2S_OUT, it connects to the I2S data input of a compatible I2S audio peripheral. This peripheral could be a DAC, ADC, or DSP that understands the I2S protocol.

implementation.connectivity: The PCM_OUT pin should be connected to the data input of an external audio codec or processing unit. When configured as I2S_OUT, it connects to the I2S data input of a compatible audio peripheral. The pin should be connected to the input of the downstream audio device.
implementation.detailed_description: PCM_OUT is a digital output signal used for transmitting Pulse Code Modulation (PCM) data. PCM is a method used to digitally represent analog signals. In the context of this module, it's used for audio communication.
implementation.functionality: This pin can also be configured as I2S_OUT (Inter-IC Sound). The functionality (PCM or I2S) depends on the selected configuration mode within the module's firmware.
precautions: The functionality (PCM or I2S) must be configured via the module's firmware.
Ensure the output voltage level (1.8V) is compatible with the connected external audio device.

The 'If Unused' state for PCM_OUT is 'Leave open'. However, if configured as I2S_OUT, the recommendation changes to 'Pull Down'. Therefore, if the pin is not used, it should be left open unless I2S configuration is intended, in which case it should be pulled down.
Refer to the specific audio codec or processing unit datasheet for its input requirements and recommended external components.

PCM_OUT.name: PCM_OUT

PCM_SYNC.description:
PCM Sync
The frame synchronization signal delivers
an 16 kHz frequency pulse that
synchronizes the frame data in and the
frame data out.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect the PCM_SYNC pin (Pin 35) of the RC76xx module to the corresponding synchronization input pin of the audio codec or peripheral device.
The pin has an internal pull-down resistor, which is active in the reset state.

implementation.connectivity: The PCM_SYNC pin should be connected to the corresponding synchronization pin of the audio codec or peripheral. In PCM Master mode, the module drives this signal. The pin has an internal pull-down resistor, but it is also specified to be 'Leave open' if unused, suggesting it is not actively pulled high by default and might rely on the connected peripheral for signal level maintenance in some configurations.
implementation.detailed_description: The PCM_SYNC signal is a frame synchronization signal. In PCM Master mode, it delivers a 16 kHz frequency pulse that synchronizes the frame data in and the frame data out. This signal is crucial for aligning the audio data stream between the module and the audio peripheral.
implementation.functionality: The PCM_SYNC signal acts as both an input and output. In PCM Master mode, it functions as an output to synchronize the audio peripheral. It also has a secondary function as an input, potentially for specific configurations or future enhancements, although its primary role in Master mode is as an output synchronizer.
precautions: In PCM Master mode, the module drives the PCM_SYNC signal. Ensure the connected audio peripheral is configured to accept this synchronization signal.
If the PCM_SYNC pin is not used, it should be left open. However, it also has an internal pull-down resistor.
The reset state has an internal pull-down, which might affect the signal level if not properly managed during initialization.
The datasheet mentions 'Input/Output in Primary mode', implying that while it's primarily an output in Master mode, there might be specific input uses or configurations to be aware of.

PCM_SYNC.name: PCM_SYNC

connected_components.description: A GPIO pin from the host microcontroller can be used to control the POWER_ON_N pin, allowing software-initiated power control.
A momentary push button or switch can be connected between the POWER_ON_N pin and ground to allow manual power control.
An external open collector or open drain transistor can be used to drive the POWER_ON_N pin to ground.
The pin has an internal pull-up resistor. The nominal voltage when floating is approximately 0.8V.

implementation.connectivity: The pin should be connected to a control mechanism (e.g., a button, switch, or a host processor's GPIO) that can drive it to ground when needed to power on or off the module. It is internally pulled-up, so no external pull-up resistor should be added.
implementation.detailed_description: The POWER_ON_N pin is a low-level signal used to switch the Semtech RC76xx module ON or OFF. It is internally pulled-up. To turn the module ON, this pin should be connected to ground for at least 200 ms and not more than approximately 7 seconds. If it remains grounded for longer than 7 seconds, the module will start and then power off once the pin is released. To turn the module OFF via software, the AT!POWERDOWN command should be used. Asserting POWER_ON_N to low for more than 1 second while the module is in an active power state will also turn the module OFF.
implementation.functionality: The pin's primary function is to control the power state of the module, switching it between ON and OFF. It also plays a role in the power-up sequence and can initiate a power-off sequence.
precautions: Do not design any external pull-up circuit on this pin, as it is internally pulled-up. This could cause damage or abnormal power-on behavior.

If the module experiences six consecutive under-voltage lockout (UVLO) events less than approximately 45 seconds apart without a host-initiated power down or reset, the device enters a mode where only the DM port enumerates on the USB.
When powering on the module, ensure POWER_ON_N is asserted low for at least 200 ms and not more than ~7s.
If POWER_ON_N remains connected to GND for more than ~7s, the module will start and turn off once POWER_ON_N is released.
When the module is in PSM or off mode, the VGPIO pin is in high impedance. Ensure connected signals are in a high impedance or floating state to avoid extra power consumption.

connected_components.component_name: Host platform control mechanism (e.g., button, switch, jumper)

implementation.connectivity: The RESET_IN_N pin should be connected to a control mechanism on the host platform, such as a button, switch, or jumper. It should be an open-drain or open-collector connection to ground.
implementation.detailed_description: The RESET_IN_N pin is an input signal used to reset the Semtech RC76xx module. A low level pulse applied to this pin will immediately restart the module. This reset action affects the CPU registers and RAM memory for the next power-on cycle. It is intended for emergency situations where the module may become unresponsive.
implementation.functionality: This pin can be used for both a standard reset and an emergency power-off function. A short low pulse initiates a reset. Holding the pin low for an extended duration (at least 8 seconds) while POWER_ON_N is de-asserted results in an emergency power-off.
precautions: Do not design any external pull-up circuit on this pin to avoid damage or abnormal reset signals.
This pin should only be used for emergencies if the system freezes (not responding to commands).
Using RESET_IN_N inappropriately can lead to memory corruption; it is recommended to use a power cycle instead when possible.
When using RESET_IN_N for an emergency power off, ensure POWER_ON_N is de-asserted.
If the module is in PSM, asserting RESET_IN_N will wake it up and perform a reset.

implementation.connected_components: This pin is typically connected to the reset input of peripheral devices such as USB hubs, I2C devices, etc.
implementation.connectivity: It is an output pin from the module.
implementation.detailed_description: This pin can be used to provide a signal that will hold peripheral devices (such as a USB hub, I2C device, etc.) in reset until the power-up sequence is complete.
implementation.functionality:
When the module is:
* In reset or powering up—this pin is held low to put peripheral devices in reset. Once the power-on sequence is complete, this pin will be turned high to take the peripherals out from reset.
* In PSM—this pin will keep its previous status.
implementation.precautions:
This pin is controlled by GPIO6. To configure this pin as a Reset output:
1. Disable external SIM switch feature using AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",0.
2. Configure GPIO6 using AT+WIOCFG=6,0.
3. Reboot the module.
For details, refer to the Semtech RC76xx AT Command Reference guide.

connected_components.details: An external antenna specifically designed for diversity reception is required. This antenna should be connected to the RF_DIV pin. The antenna's characteristics, such as impedance and frequency range, should be compatible with the module's specifications and the cellular bands being used.
The RF_DIV pin is associated with ground pads (Pin 30 and Pin 32) which must be connected to the module's ground plane for proper RF signal integrity and shielding.

implementation.connectivity: The RF_DIV pin should be connected to the diversity antenna. It is an input pin to the module.
implementation.detailed_description: The RF_DIV pin is the Diversity Antenna Interface. It is used for receiving signals to improve reception quality by using a second antenna to capture signals that may be missed by the primary antenna.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the input for the diversity antenna, which is used in conjunction with the primary antenna (RF_MAIN) to improve the module's reception capabilities through antenna diversity.
precautions: The RF_DIV pin, along with its associated ground pins, must be connected to the diversity antenna. This connection is crucial for enabling antenna diversity functionality.
Proper routing of the RF trace for RF_DIV is recommended to maintain signal integrity. Refer to Section 5.7.3 'RF Routing Recommendations' for detailed guidelines.

The antenna system, including the diversity antenna connected to RF_DIV, should meet the recommendations outlined in Table 3-30 'Antenna Recommendations', particularly regarding VSWR, total radiated efficiency, and isolation between antennas.

connected_components.description: The antenna must be designed to operate within the GNSS frequency bands (typically around 1575.42 MHz for GPS L1, and other frequencies for GLONASS, BeiDou, Galileo). Recommendations for antenna characteristics such as frequency range, field of view, gain, and polarization are provided in the datasheet (Table 3-33).
The RF_GNSS pin should be connected to ground planes (pins 37 and 39) for proper RF signal integrity and shielding, as indicated in the datasheet.

implementation.connectivity: The RF_GNSS pin should be connected to a GNSS antenna.  It is recommended to follow specific routing guidelines for RF signals to ensure optimal performance.
implementation.detailed_description: The RF_GNSS pin is the radio frequency input for the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receiver. It allows the module to receive signals from GNSS satellites for location determination.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the primary interface for the GNSS antenna. Its functionality is solely dedicated to receiving GNSS RF signals.
precautions: RF_GNSS is an input pin and therefore susceptible to ESD. ESD protection should be implemented on this line, especially if the antenna is externally accessible. Refer to section 5.9 EMC and ESD Recommendations and Table 5-1 for ESD specifications.

The routing of the RF_GNSS trace requires careful consideration to maintain signal integrity and minimize losses. It is recommended to use a Conductor-Backed Coplanar Waveguide (CBCPW) and follow the routing constraints detailed in section 5.7.3 RF Routing Recommendations.
The datasheet specifies that the maximum voltage applied to antenna interface pins should not exceed 6.3 VDC.
Ensure that the antenna system provides adequate isolation (> 20 dB) between the GNSS antenna and any WWAN antennas to prevent interference.

connected_components.details: The RF_MAIN pin connects to the primary antenna responsible for transmitting and receiving cellular signals. The antenna should be selected based on the supported frequency bands and performance requirements.

Multiple GND pins (e.g., Pin 48, Pin 50, Pin 136, Pin 139) are recommended to be connected to the RF_MAIN pin's ground connection. This ensures a solid RF ground reference and aids in signal integrity and thermal dissipation.
A controlled impedance transmission line (e.g., microstrip or coplanar waveguide) should be used to connect the RF_MAIN pin to the antenna. The impedance should typically be 50 Ohms.

implementation.connectivity: This pin must be connected to the primary WWAN antenna through a suitable RF transmission line. It should also be connected to Ground (GND) pins for proper RF grounding.
implementation.detailed_description: The RF_MAIN pin is the primary interface for the module's radio frequency (RF) signals. It serves as both an input for receiving RF signals and an output for transmitting RF signals.
implementation.functionality: This pin is the main antenna interface for the module, connecting to the primary WWAN antenna. It is used for both transmitting and receiving RF signals across various cellular technologies supported by the module (LTE, UMTS, GSM/GPRS/EDGE).
precautions: RF Routing: The trace connected to RF_MAIN must be routed according to RF routing recommendations to maintain signal integrity and minimize losses. This includes using controlled impedance traces and proper grounding.
Grounding: Ensure adequate grounding for the RF_MAIN pin by connecting it to multiple GND pads and ground planes.
Signal Integrity: Avoid routing other signals near the RF_MAIN trace to prevent interference and signal degradation.

Antenna Selection: The choice of antenna and its placement are critical for RF performance. Ensure the antenna is compatible with the module's supported frequency bands and meets VSWR and efficiency requirements.

ESD Protection: While not explicitly stated for this pin, it is good practice to consider ESD protection for RF interfaces, especially if exposed to user contact or harsh environments. Consult EMC and ESD Recommendations in Section 5.9.
Maximum Voltage: Do not exceed the maximum voltage applied to antenna interface pins, which is 6.3 VDC as per Table 3-34.

SAFE_PWR_REMOVE.description:
Indicate to host
that Main DC power
can be removed

implementation.connected_components: This pin is intended to be connected to the host system's power management circuitry or a microcontroller's GPIO pin that controls the VBATT supply.
implementation.connectivity: This pin is an output from the RC76xx module and should be connected to the host system's power management or control logic. The host system should monitor this signal to determine when it is safe to remove power from the module. It is recommended that all host interfaces connected to the module be disabled (set to high impedance or pull-down) before VBATT is switched off.
implementation.detailed_description: The SAFE_PWR_REMOVE signal is an output from the Semtech RC76xx module that indicates to the host device that the main power supply (VBATT) can be safely turned off.
implementation.functionality: This signal provides a positive pulse to signal to the host that it is safe to remove the main power supply (VBATT). The pulse width is approximately 13.26 ms. After this pulse, there is a delay of 7.8 ms from the falling edge of SAFE_PWR_REMOVE to VGPIO turning off.
implementation.precautions: The host system must monitor this signal before removing VBATT. It is also important to consider the VGPIO discharge time (which depends on the load on the host equipment) before switching off VBATT. All host interfaces connected to the module should be disabled before VBATT is switched off to prevent leakages and ensure proper power-on sequences.

SAFE_PWR_REMOVE.name: SAFE_PWR_REMOVE

connected_components.component_description: An external microcontroller or other peripheral device that requires a low-frequency clock signal for its operation (e.g., for real-time clock functions, low-power timing, or maintaining system state during module sleep periods).

A small decoupling capacitor (e.g., 0.1 uF) may be placed in parallel with the connection to ground to help filter any high-frequency noise, although this is typically not strictly necessary for a low-frequency clock output.

implementation.connectivity: The SLEEP_CLK pin should be connected to the clock input of any external component requiring a low-frequency clock signal. The connection should be made via a signal trace. No external pull-up or pull-down resistors are typically required for this output pin.
implementation.detailed_description: The SLEEP_CLK pin provides a 32.768 kHz digital clock output from the module. This clock signal is derived from an internal real-time clock.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of SLEEP_CLK is to provide a low-frequency clock signal. It is typically used for low-power timing or real-time clock functions in external circuitry when the main module is in a low-power state. It is not a wakeable pin.
precautions: The SLEEP_CLK pin is an output and should not be driven by external circuitry to avoid potential damage to the module.
While typically not required, ensure proper trace routing for signal integrity, especially if the trace is long or routed near noisy signals.
If the pin is not used, it should be left unconnected ('Leave open') as per the datasheet recommendations to avoid any potential interference or unexpected behavior.

connected_components.component_description: Any SPI-compatible slave device that requires a clock signal for serial communication. This could include sensors, memory devices, or other microcontrollers configured as SPI slaves.

implementation.connectivity: SPI1_CLK should be connected to the CLK (or SCLK) input of the SPI slave device.
implementation.detailed_description: SPI1_CLK is the serial clock signal for the SPI1 bus. It is output from the master (the Semtech RC76xx module) and controls the timing of data transfer on the MOSI and MISO lines.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the serial clock output for the SPI1 bus. It is used in master mode operation for the Semtech RC76xx module to synchronize data transfer with a connected SPI slave device. The clock frequency can range up to 38 MHz.
precautions: Ensure the SPI clock speed does not exceed the capabilities of the connected SPI slave device.
Maintain signal integrity for the clock signal, especially at higher frequencies, by following PCB layout recommendations for high-speed signals.
The pin has an output capability and should not be driven externally when the module is acting as a master.

SPI1_MISO.description:
SPI Master Input/Slave Output
(output from slave)

implementation.connected_components: The SPI1_MISO pin needs to be connected to the MOSI pin of the SPI slave device that the RC76xx module is communicating with. The specific nature of the slave device would depend on the application.
implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, SPI1_MISO should be connected to the MOSI (Master Output / Slave Input) pin of the connected SPI slave device.  The RC76xx module acts as the master in this scenario.
implementation.detailed_description: SPI1_MISO is the Master Input / Slave Output pin for the SPI1 bus. In the context of the RC76xx module, it functions as the data output from the slave device when the module is operating as a master in SPI communication.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the Master Input / Slave Output for the SPI1 bus. It's used by the RC76xx module when it acts as an SPI master to receive data from a connected SPI slave device.
implementation.precautions: The RC76xx module operates as an SPI master on this bus. Ensure that the connected slave device is configured correctly to communicate with the master. The default state of this pin when unused is 'Leave open'.

SPI1_MISO.name: SPI1_MISO

SPI1_MOSI.description:
SPI Master Output/Slave Input (output
from master)

connected_components.connection_details: Connect directly to the MOSI (Master Out Slave In) pin of the SPI Slave device. Ensure proper impedance matching and trace routing as per the datasheet's recommendations for high-speed digital signals.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic where the RC76xx module is the SPI Master, the SPI1_MOSI pin should be connected to the MOSI (Master Out Slave In) pin of the SPI Slave device. This creates the data transmission path from the module to the slave device. The connection should be a direct trace on the PCB, ideally with impedance matching considerations if operating at higher speeds or over longer distances, as per the datasheet's RF Routing Recommendations, though SPI is a digital interface.
