implementation.detailed_description: SPI1_MOSI (Master Output, Slave Input) is a serial data line used in the SPI (Serial Peripheral Interface) communication protocol. When the RC76xx module acts as the SPI Master, this pin transmits data to the SPI Slave device. Conversely, when the module is configured as an SPI Slave (though not supported in Master mode operation by this module), it would receive data from the SPI Master on this pin.
implementation.functionality: When the RC76xx is acting as an SPI Master, SPI1_MOSI serves as an output pin to transmit data to the connected SPI Slave device. The data transmitted is determined by the SPI communication being performed. While the module itself operates in Master mode, the pin's designation as 'Master Output/Slave Input' highlights its role in the SPI bus. It is not designed to be a general-purpose input/output pin when used as part of the SPI interface.
precautions: The SPI1_MOSI pin is specifically for SPI communication and should not be used as a general-purpose I/O pin when the SPI interface is active.
Ensure proper impedance matching for the trace connecting SPI1_MOSI to the SPI slave, especially for longer trace lengths or higher SPI clock frequencies, to maintain signal integrity.
Refer to the datasheet's routing recommendations for high-speed digital signals, particularly regarding ground planes and trace separation, to minimize noise and interference.

SPI1_MOSI.name: SPI1_MOSI

connected_components.connection_description: Connected to the SPI1_MRDY output of the RC76xx module. The specific function of the connected pin on the slave device or microcontroller would depend on how it's designed to interpret the 'Master Ready' signal from the RC76xx. This could be an interrupt input, a status check input, or a general-purpose input.

implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected as an output from the Semtech RC76xx module. In a schematic, it would be an output pin from the module that connects to a corresponding input or control pin on the SPI slave device or the host system's microcontroller that is managing the SPI communication.
implementation.detailed_description: SPI1_MRDY (SPI Master Ready) is an output signal from the Semtech RC76xx module related to the SPI bus interface. In the context of SPI communication, this signal likely indicates the readiness of the SPI master (the RC76xx module) to engage in communication or to signal a specific state regarding its readiness.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as an output signal indicating the SPI master's readiness. Its specific behavior (e.g., active low or high, pulsed or continuous) would depend on the SPI protocol implementation and how it's configured via AT commands. It is part of the SPI1 interface.
precautions: The pin is an output and should not be driven externally. The RC76xx module controls its state.
Ensure proper signal routing for SPI communication to maintain signal integrity, as described in Section 5.7.3 RF Routing Recommendations and Section 5.7.4 USB Interface of the datasheet.
The default state of this pin is 'Internal Pull-Down' in active status.
Refer to the RC76xx AT Command Reference for any specific configuration commands related to SPI functionality, such as `AT!CUSTOM` or `+WIOCFG` if applicable to SPI behavior.

connected_components.component_function: Receives the system clock signal from SYS_CLK to synchronize its operations.
connected_components.connection_details: Connected to a clock input pin of the host's main processing unit.

connected_components.component_function: May utilize the SYS_CLK signal for their timing or synchronization needs.
connected_components.connection_details: Connected to the clock input of any peripheral device requiring this clock signal.

implementation.connectivity: The SYS_CLK pin should be connected to the clock input of the host system's microcontroller, processor, or any other peripheral requiring a system clock signal. A direct connection is recommended.
implementation.detailed_description: The SYS_CLK pin is a digital clock output signal provided by the module's Power Management Integrated Circuit (PMIC). It outputs a stable 19.2 MHz clock signal. This signal is intended for use by the host system or other connected peripherals that require a system clock reference.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves a single primary function: to provide a 19.2 MHz system clock output. It is not described as having different functions based on connectivity.
precautions: The SYS_CLK signal should not be loaded with more than the specified drive capability to avoid signal degradation.
Avoid routing the SYS_CLK trace near sensitive analog signals or RF traces to prevent noise injection or interference.
Ensure the trace length for SYS_CLK is kept as short as possible to minimize signal integrity issues and impedance mismatches.
The SYS_CLK pin is an output and should not be driven by external circuitry.

implementation.connected_components: When used for boot-loader mode: a button, switch, or jumper. When used for testing: a test point.
implementation.connectivity: If used to force boot-loader mode, it should be connected to a control mechanism (button, switch, or jumper) that asserts the pin low during power-up. If not used for boot-loader mode, it should be connected to a test point.
implementation.detailed_description: The TP1 pin (boot pin) is used to force the module to enter boot-loader mode on power-up. When the module is not connected to a control mechanism, it should be connected to a test point for RMA and debug purposes.
implementation.functionality:
The pin has two primary functions: 
1. Force the module into boot-loader mode on power-up by connecting it to a control mechanism (e.g., button, switch, or jumper) and asserting it low.
2. Serve as a test point for RMA and debug purposes if not connected to a control mechanism.
implementation.precautions: If forcing boot-loader mode, ensure the TP1 pin is de-asserted after the module restarts and enters boot-loader mode. If the pin is not connected to a control mechanism, it must be connected to a test point for RMA and debug. Firmware downloads can also occur over USB or OTA.

implementation.connected_components: The datasheet indicates that this pin can be connected to the host system or external circuitry that needs to monitor transmit activity.
implementation.connectivity: The TX_ON pin is an output from the module. It should be connected to a host system or external circuitry that needs to be notified of transmit activity. The datasheet suggests it is an 'Indication' pin.
implementation.detailed_description: The TX_ON pin is a digital output signal provided by the Semtech RC76xx module that indicates the occurrence of Transmit (Tx) activity. When the module is actively transmitting, this signal goes high. When there is no transmission activity, the signal goes low.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the TX_ON pin is to signal transmit activity. It does not appear to serve different functions based on connectivity in the provided datasheet excerpt.
implementation.precautions: The datasheet provides timing characteristics for the TX_ON signal (Tadvance and Tdelay), which may be relevant for precise synchronization with external components. Specifically, the advance time is 64.8 ms (LTE) / 20 ms (3G) / 150 µs (2G) and the delay is up to 33.8 ms (LTE) / 800 ms (3G) / 50 µs (2G). It is important to consider these timing parameters when integrating this signal with other components to ensure proper synchronization.

connected_components.connection_description: Connect to the CTS (Clear To Send) input pin of the host device's UART controller.
connected_components.name: Host Device

implementation.connectivity: UART1_CTS should be connected from the module's pin to the corresponding CTS (Clear To Send) input pin on the host device.
implementation.detailed_description: UART1_CTS is the Clear To Send signal for the UART1 interface, used for flow control in serial communication. It indicates to the transmitting device that the receiving device is ready to receive data.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of UART1_CTS is to serve as a flow control signal for the UART1 interface. It is an output from the module to the host.
precautions: It is highly recommended to connect this pin for flow control.
The signal direction is an output from the module to the host.
The pin has a default state of Pull Down in active status.

It is recommended to reserve a pull-up resistor design on UART1_TX and UART1_RX pins, with a typical value of 100k Ohm, if there is no pull-up setting on the host side or to avoid unclear signal levels when the host is in low power mode. This value depends on the application and used hardware.

UART1_DCD.description:
Data Carrier Detect
Signal data
connection in
progress

implementation.connected_components: An external pull-down resistor (value to be determined based on application specifics, typically in the kOhm range) is recommended to ensure a defined low state when the module is not actively indicating data carrier detection. The module itself drives this pin.
implementation.connectivity: It is connected as an output from the module. For robust signal integrity and to prevent potential boot issues if the pin is pulled high unexpectedly, it is highly recommended to install an external pull-down resistor on this pin when the UART interface is used.
implementation.detailed_description: The UART1_DCD (Data Carrier Detect) signal is an output from the module that indicates the status of the data connection. When a data connection is active, this signal is asserted.
implementation.functionality: The pin's primary function is to indicate the presence of a data carrier. It is an output signal from the module.
implementation.precautions: It is critical NOT to install an external pull-up resistor on this pin. Doing so can prevent the module from booting correctly. Ensure the pin is properly pulled down when not actively indicating data carrier detect. The pin is internally pulled down by default.

UART1_DCD.name: UART1_DCD

UART1_DSR.description:
Data Set Ready
Signal UART
interface is ON

connected_components.connection_details: Connected to the DSR input/output of the host's UART controller.
An internal pull-down resistor is present on the pin.

implementation.connectivity: The pin should be connected to the host device's corresponding DSR signal.  There is a strong recommendation for a mandatory connection if the UART interface is used.  Additionally, the pin has an internal pull-down resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: UART1_DSR (Data Set Ready) is an output signal from the module that indicates the status of the UART interface. Specifically, it signals that the UART interface is ON and ready for communication.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of UART1_DSR is to indicate that the UART interface is ready.  However, the pin has specific notes regarding its default state and potential boot issues if not handled correctly.  It is internally pulled down, and there's a warning against installing an external pull-up resistor, as this could prevent the module from booting.  Additionally, the pin's behavior regarding wake-up from sleep mode is mentioned, noting it will pull up if KSLEEP is set to 1 or 2, and float if KSLEEP is 0. This suggests a secondary conditional functionality related to power states.
precautions: Do not install an external pull-up resistor on this pin, otherwise the module will not boot.
The pin should be connected if the UART interface is used.
The pin's behavior regarding wake-up from sleep mode depends on the KSLEEP setting, which should be considered in the system design.

UART1_DSR.name: UART1_DSR

UART1_DTR.description:
Data terminal
ready
Prevents the
RC76xx from
entering sleep
mode, switches
between data
mode and
command mode,
and wakes the
module.

implementation.connected_components: The pin is connected to the host system's UART interface. Depending on the host's power management strategy, it might be connected to a host system's power management controller or a dedicated signal. If used for wake-up, it would be connected to a GPIO or other controllable output pin on the host.  A pull-down resistor is mentioned as a default state for the pin when unused, but specific connection details depend on the host implementation.
implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected as an input to the module. The connection strategy from the host depends on the desired behavior regarding sleep mode and wake-up events. For wake-up functionality, it should be connected to a host signal that can transition its state.
implementation.detailed_description: The UART1_DTR (Data Terminal Ready) signal is an input to the module that is used to manage the data terminal ready status. It can prevent the RC76xx from entering sleep mode, switch between data mode and command mode, and wake up the module. The pin's behavior regarding sleep mode is dependent on the KSLEEP setting.
implementation.functionality: This pin can serve multiple functions: preventing the module from entering sleep mode, switching between data and command modes, and waking the module. Its behavior related to sleep mode is influenced by the KSLEEP setting, where it will be floating when KSLEEP=0 and pull-up when KSLEEP=1 or 2.
implementation.precautions: The pin is described as 'wakeable', meaning it can trigger the module to wake up from sleep mode. When the module is in PSM, this pin is not a recognized wakeup source.  Additionally, the pin's behavior regarding sleep mode is dependent on the KSLEEP setting. If the host side has no pull-up setting or is in a low power mode, it's recommended to reserve a pull-up resistor design on the UART1_RX and UART1_TX pins, which might indirectly influence the overall UART interface design. The default state of the pin is a pull-down.

UART1_DTR.name: UART1_DTR

UART1_RI.description:
Ring Indicator
Signal incoming
calls (voice and
data), SMS, etc.

connected_components.description: An input pin on the host device designed to receive the Ring Indicator signal, typically an interrupt input.
A resistor connected between the UART1_RI pin and ground. Its value is typically selected to ensure a low logic level when the module is in its reset or boot state.

implementation.connectivity: The UART1_RI pin should be connected to an input on the host device that can detect a low-level pulse. It is also recommended to have a pull-down resistor on this pin, which is the default reset state. An external pull-up resistor should NOT be installed on this pin, as it can prevent the module from booting.
implementation.detailed_description: The UART1_RI pin is an output signal from the module that functions as a Ring Indicator. It is used to notify an external application about various events, such as incoming calls (voice and data), incoming SMS messages, or timer expirations. The module pulses this signal low when such an event occurs.
implementation.functionality: The UART1_RI pin can be used independently from the main UART1 interface. Its behavior, specifically the pulse width, can be configured using the AT+WRID command. It also supports events that toggle the RI signal and can be configured as a wakeup source for the module from a sleep state using the AT+WWAKESET AT command.
precautions: Do not install an external pull-up resistor on this pin, as it can prevent the module from booting.
The pulse width of the signal can be configured using the AT+WRID AT command.
The signal can be used to wake the module from a sleep state if configured via the AT+WWAKESET AT command.
The pin has an internal pull-down resistor.

UART1_RI.name: UART1_RI

connected_components.connection_details: Connect the UART1_RTS pin of the module to the RTS input pin of the host's UART controller.

Although the pin has an internal pull-down, an external pull-down resistor can be added for robustness.  The default state is pulled down, and it is asserted (driven low) by the module when ready to receive.

implementation.connectivity: UART1_RTS should be connected to the RTS (Ready To Send) input pin of the host UART controller.  It is a unidirectional signal originating from the module.
implementation.detailed_description: UART1_RTS (Ready To Send) is a flow control signal for the UART1 interface. It indicates to the connected device (e.g., host processor) whether the module is ready to receive data.
implementation.functionality: UART1_RTS is an output signal from the module. When the module is ready to receive data from the host, it asserts this signal (typically by driving it low). When the module is not ready (e.g., its receive buffer is full), it de-asserts this signal (typically by letting it float or pulling it down). This allows the connected device to pause transmission to avoid data overflow.
precautions: Highly Recommended to connect for proper flow control.
The pin has an internal pull-down resistor, but an external pull-down is recommended for robust operation.
Ensure the host UART controller's RTS input is correctly configured to interpret the signal from the module.

connected_components.component_description: The transmit pin of the host's Universal Asynchronous Receiver-Transmitter interface.
A resistor (typically 100 kΩ) connected between the UART1_RX pin and VGPIO, used to ensure a defined signal level when the host is in low power mode or lacks its own pull-up.
Used to connect the UART1_RX pin to a test point for debug and diagnostic purposes.

implementation.connectivity: The UART1_RX pin should be connected to the transmit (TX) pin of the host UART interface. It is recommended to reserve a pull-up resistor (typically 100 kΩ) on this pin if the host side does not have a pull-up setting or to avoid unclear signal levels when the host is in low power mode. The pin should be connected through a 0 ohm resistor if it needs to be accessible via test points.
implementation.detailed_description: UART1_RX is the receive data signal for the primary UART interface. It is used for data communication between the module and a host processor or PC. The signal is an output from the module to the host.
implementation.functionality: The pin serves as the primary UART receive data line. It is used for transmitting data from the module to the host. It can also be configured to wake the module from sleep mode when a specific signal level transition occurs.
precautions: If the host side does not have a pull-up setting, or to avoid unclear signal levels when the host is in low power mode, it is recommended to reserve a pull-up resistor (typically 100 kΩ) on this pin.
The pin is 'wakeable', meaning it can trigger the module to wake up from sleep mode. Ensure this behavior is managed appropriately in the application design.
When the module is in reset or powering down, it is recommended to place the UART1_RX pin in a high impedance state or floating.
Do not install an external pull-up resistor on this pin if the module is intended to boot correctly, as it can cause boot issues.
This signal is named with respect to the host device. The direction listed (output) is with respect to the module.

connected_components.connection: Connected between UART1_TX and VGPIO (1.8V). A typical value is 100 kΩ. This is recommended if there is no pull-up setting on the host side, or to avoid unclear signal levels when the host is in low power mode.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the RX pin of the UART interface on the host device.
implementation.detailed_description: UART1_TX is a transmit data pin for the primary UART interface. This interface is used for data communication between the module and a PC or host processor. It complies with the RS-232 interface.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the transmit data output for the primary UART interface (UART1).
precautions: It is recommended to reserve a pull-up resistor design on UART1_TX. The typical resistor value is 100 kΩ. This value depends on the application and used hardware.
UART signals are named with respect to the host device, and directions are listed with respect to the module. Therefore, UART1_TX is an input to the module from the host.

If the host side does not have a pull-up setting, or to avoid any unclear signal level when the host side is in low power mode, it is recommended to reserve a pull-up resistor design on UART1_TX and UART1_RX pins.

implementation.connected_components: The primary component to be connected is the host device's UART2 interface, specifically its RTS (Request To Send) pin. The document also suggests a pull-down resistor might be used, though it's not explicitly listed as a 'connected component' but rather a characteristic of the pin's behavior if unused.
implementation.connectivity: The UART2_CTS pin should be connected to the UART2_RTS (Request To Send) pin of the host device. A highly recommended connection is implied for flow control.
implementation.detailed_description: UART2_CTS (Clear To Send) is an output signal from the module that functions as a flow control signal for the UART2 interface. It indicates when the module is ready to receive data.
implementation.functionality: The pin's primary function is as a flow control signal (Clear To Send) for the UART2 interface. It is also designated as an Extension type pin, indicating it provides additional capabilities beyond core functions.
implementation.precautions: The connection is described as 'Highly Recommended', implying that proper implementation of flow control via this pin is important for reliable UART communication. If the pin is left unused, it has a pull-down state in reset and active normal mode.

connected_components.connection: Connect UART2_RTS on the module to the RTS pin on the host device.
Optional, connected between the UART2_RTS pin and VDD_IO (1.8V) on the host side if needed for signal integrity or low power scenarios. Typical value is 100k Ohm.

implementation.connectivity: Connect this pin to the corresponding RTS pin on the host device. It is recommended to reserve a pull-up resistor on this pin on the host side if there is no pull-up setting, or to avoid unclear signal levels when the host is in low power mode. The typical resistor value is 100k Ohm, but this depends on the application and hardware used. It is also recommended to keep this pin accessible through a 0 ohm resistor and have a test point at the module side.
implementation.detailed_description: UART2_RTS (Request To Send) is a signal used for flow control in serial communication. It is an output from the module to the host, indicating that the module is ready to send data.
implementation.functionality: Primarily used for flow control in UART2 serial communication. It is an output signal from the module, indicating its readiness to transmit data.
precautions: It is recommended to reserve a pull-up resistor on this pin on the host side if there is no pull-up setting, or to avoid unclear signal levels when the host is in low power mode. The typical resistor value is 100k Ohm, but this depends on the application and hardware used.
It is recommended to keep this pin accessible through a 0 ohm resistor and have a test point at the module side for potential debugging or testing.

connected_components.component_description: The transmit pin of the host's UART interface, which will send data to the module's UART2_RX.
If the host UART voltage levels differ from the module's 1.8V logic, a level shifter is recommended to ensure proper signal compatibility.

implementation.connectivity: UART2_RX should be connected to the transmit data line (UART2_TX) of the host device or debug interface. It is recommended to connect it via a level shifter if the host device's UART voltage levels are different from the module's 1.8V logic.
implementation.detailed_description: UART2_RX is the receive data line for the secondary UART interface. This interface is primarily for internal Semtech debug purposes.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of UART2_RX is to receive data. Its usage is generally restricted to internal debug operations. In some contexts, it might be configured as a general purpose I/O, but this is not its primary or recommended use.
precautions: This pin is primarily for internal Semtech debug and not intended for general customer use. Use with caution.
Ensure proper voltage level translation if connecting to a host UART operating at different voltage levels.
When not in use, it is recommended to leave this pin unconnected to avoid unintended behavior.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect to the RX pin of the UART interface on the host device or debug equipment.
A pull-down resistor (e.g., 10 kΩ) can be connected to ground if the pin is unused to maintain a defined logic level.

implementation.connectivity: When used, UART2_TX should be connected to the RX pin of the corresponding UART interface on the host device or debug equipment. A pull-down resistor is recommended on this pin if it is not used, to maintain a defined logic level. If the interface is not needed, it can be left unconnected.
implementation.detailed_description: UART2_TX is a transmit data line for the secondary UART interface. This interface is primarily intended for internal Semtech debug purposes.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of UART2_TX is to transmit data for the secondary UART interface. It is intended for internal debug and is not typically exposed for general customer use. While it is listed as part of the UART2 interface, its primary use case is internal to Semtech.
precautions: This pin is primarily for internal Semtech debug and may not be intended for general customer use.
If not used, a pull-down resistor is recommended to ensure a defined logic level.
When connecting to external equipment, ensure voltage level compatibility.
Refer to the AT Command Reference guide for any specific configurations related to UART2 usage.

connected_components.description: The UIM Card (Subscriber Identity Module) interfaces with the module via the UIM interface, including the UIM1_CLK pin for clock synchronization.
A physical connector for the UIM card, which facilitates the electrical connection between the UIM card and the module.
An ESD suppressor diode array (e.g., STMicroelectronics DALC208SC6) is recommended to be placed on the UIM1_CLK line to protect against electrostatic discharge.
A capacitor (e.g., 1nF) may be used as a placeholder for potential layout issues, connected in series with the UIM1_CLK trace.
A resistor (e.g., RCLK, typically around 15kΩ) may be used as a placeholder for potential layout issues, connected in series with the UIM1_CLK trace.

implementation.connectivity: UIM1_CLK should be connected directly from the module's UIM1_CLK pin to the UIM card's CLK pin. It is recommended to keep this trace as short as possible.
implementation.detailed_description: UIM1_CLK is the clock signal output from the module to the UIM card. This clock signal synchronizes the communication between the module and the UIM card, following the ISO/IEC 7816 standard.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of UIM1_CLK is to provide the clock signal for UIM communication. The frequency of this clock is controlled by the module and may vary based on the UIM standard and the module's configuration.
precautions: The trace for UIM1_CLK should be kept as short as possible.
ESD protection is mandatory on this pin unless an external eSIM is used or there is no physical access to the UIM.
Optional series resistors and capacitors are recommended as placeholders for layout considerations.
Ensure the voltage level of UIM1_CLK is compatible with the UIM card's operating voltage (1.8V or 2.85V).

connected_components.connection_details: Connect to the DATA pin of the UIM card holder or eSIM.
Connected to UIM1_DATA for ESD protection. Example: STMicroelectronics DALC208SC6.
Connected in series with a 0-ohm resistor, with a value of 15 kOhms. This is for potential layout adjustments and protection.

implementation.connectivity: The UIM1_DATA pin should be connected to the corresponding DATA pin on the UIM card holder or eSIM. It is also recommended to have a mandatory connection to the module's UIM1_DATA pin. Additionally, an ESD suppressor diode array and a 0-ohm resistor in series with a 15k Ohm resistor (RDATA) are recommended to be connected to this pin for protection and potential layout adjustments.
implementation.detailed_description: UIM1_DATA is the data connection for the UIM1 interface, which allows for communication with a Subscriber Identity Module (SIM) card. This bidirectional data line is part of the UIM interface, which adheres to ETSI TS 102 221 standards for SIM card communication.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as the bidirectional data line for the UIM1 interface, facilitating the exchange of data between the module and the SIM card. It supports both sending and receiving data for SIM card operations.
precautions: The UIM1_DATA trace should be routed away from the UIM1_CLK trace to minimize interference.
Keep the distance between the module and the UIM holder as short as possible.
All signals near the UIM holder must be ESD-protected.
An ESD device specifically designed for UIM cards is recommended for this pin.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect the UIM1_RESET_N pin directly to the RESET pin of the UIM card holder.
connected_components.description: The UIM1_RESET_N pin connects to the RESET pin of the UIM card holder. The UIM holder facilitates the physical connection of the SIM card to the module.

connected_components.component_name: ESD Suppressor Diode Array (e.g., STMicroelectronics DALC208SC6)
connected_components.connection_details: Place the ESD suppressor diode array between the UIM1_RESET_N pin and ground, or as per the suppressor's datasheet recommendations.
connected_components.description: It is recommended to have ESD protection on the UIM interface signals, including UIM1_RESET_N. An ESD suppressor diode array is suggested to protect against electrostatic discharge.

connected_components.connection_details: Consult the specific schematic in Figure 5-8 for the recommended connection of resistors and capacitors around the UIM interface. It shows placeholder resistors RCLK and RDATA which might have pull-up functionality.
connected_components.description: While not explicitly stated for UIM1_RESET_N, a pull-up resistor is sometimes used in UIM interfaces to ensure a defined high state. However, the document emphasizes not adding external pull-ups where not specified.

implementation.connectivity: The UIM1_RESET_N pin should be connected to the RESET pin of the UIM card holder. The Semtech RC76xx module drives this signal, and it is crucial to connect it directly to the UIM interface for proper operation.
implementation.detailed_description: The UIM1_RESET_N pin is an output signal from the Semtech RC76xx module that controls the reset state of the UIM (Universal Identity Module) interface. It is used to initialize or reset the SIM card inserted into the UIM1 slot. The pin is typically driven low by the module to reset the SIM card and then driven high to allow the SIM card to operate normally.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of UIM1_RESET_N is to reset the UIM interface. The documentation does not indicate that this pin serves different functions based on connectivity.
precautions: The UIM1_RESET_N signal should be connected directly to the UIM card holder's RESET pin. Avoid intermediate components unless they are for ESD protection.
Ensure proper ESD protection is implemented on this pin to prevent damage to the module or the SIM card, especially if the UIM holder is accessible to the user.
When the module is booting or resetting, the UIM1_RESET_N pin has a default state, which is typically low to ensure the SIM card is reset. Ensure your design accounts for this behavior.
The UIM interface signals, including UIM1_RESET_N, must be routed away from noisy signals and kept as short as possible to maintain signal integrity.

UIM1_SIMA_DET.description:
Detect UIM1
insertion/removal.
(Pin must be open
to detect the UIM,
or grounded if no
UIM is present.)

connected_components.description: A physical socket designed to accept a UIM card. The SIM presence detect mechanism within the holder would be connected to UIM1_SIMA_DET.
A resistor (typically 470 kΩ, as mentioned in the document) connected between VGPIO and UIM1_SIMA_DET. This is recommended for proper SIM detection functionality.

implementation.connectivity: For SIM Detect functionality, it needs to be connected to the UIM holder's SIM presence detect mechanism. For General Purpose Input/Output functionality, it can be connected to other digital signals or left open if unused. An external pull-up resistor is recommended when used as a SIM detect input.
implementation.detailed_description: The UIM1_SIMA_DET pin is used to detect the physical presence of a UIM (Universal Identity Module) card in the UIM holder. It is an input to the module from the host.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves two functions: 1. SIM Detect: To detect the physical presence of a UIM card. 2. General Purpose Input/Output: Can be configured as a general-purpose input/output pin.
implementation.precautions: 1. Pin is 'wakeable': Can be used to trigger the module to wake up from sleep mode. 2. When used for SIM Detect, an external pull-up resistor is required. 3. If not used for SIM Detect or as a wakeable pin, it can be left open. 4. If used as a GPIO, the external SIM detect feature must be disabled first using AT!CUSTOM="EXTUIMSWITCHEN",0, then configure GPIO4 using AT+WIOCFG=4,4. 5. There should not be any voltage applied to the GPIOs when the module is off or resetting.

UIM1_SIMA_DET.name: UIM1_SIMA_DET

UIM1_SIMB_DET.description:
Detect UIM1_SIMB
insertion / removal /
General purpose I/
O

connected_components.description: A resistor connected between this pin and VGPIO (1.8V) to ensure a defined high logic level when no SIM is present or when used as a GPIO input.
connected_components.typical_values: 55 kΩ to 390 kΩ (general GPIO pull-up range) or 10 kΩ to 100 kΩ (specific to UIM interface detection, though not explicitly stated for this pin).

connected_components.description: The pin connects to the SIM detection pin of the secondary SIM card holder. The holder should be designed to provide a logic high signal when a SIM is inserted and a logic low (or floating) when it is removed, typically with the pull-up resistor.
If used as a GPIO, this pin can be connected to other digital components like buttons, sensors, or microcontrollers for input or output signals.

implementation.connectivity:
For SIM detection, this pin requires an external pull-up resistor. The specific value is not detailed, but external pull-up resistors are generally in the kΩ range. The pin should be connected to the detection pin of the secondary SIM card holder.
For GPIO functionality, it needs to be configured via AT commands (AT+WIOCFG=65,4) and can then be connected to other digital components as an input or output.
implementation.detailed_description: The UIM1_SIMB_DET pin is an input signal used to detect the physical presence of a UIM card in a secondary SIM holder (UIM B). It is part of the UIM interface functionality for managing dual SIM configurations. This pin is also configurable as a General Purpose Input/Output (GPIO).
implementation.functionality:
This pin serves two primary functions:
1. SIM Detect: It detects the presence or absence of a SIM card in the secondary SIM holder (UIM B). When a SIM card is inserted, the signal goes high; when removed, it goes low.
2. General Purpose Input/Output (GPIO): When not used for SIM detection, it can be configured and used as a general-purpose input/output pin for other application-specific tasks.
implementation.precautions: When used for SIM detection, ensure the external pull-up resistor is correctly sized. If the pin is configured as a GPIO, ensure the external circuit does not violate the voltage or current limits for GPIO pins. Also, note that this pin is 'wakeable', meaning it can wake the module from Sleep mode if configured as a wakeup source. The 'If Unused' state indicates 'Leave open', but for reliable SIM detection, a pull-up is required. If the pull-up is not used and the pin is left floating, it may not reliably detect the SIM state without a defined pull-up.

UIM1_SIMB_DET.name: UIM1_SIMB_DET

connected_components.component_description: A connector designed to accept a physical SIM card. The VCC pin of the holder connects to UIM1_VCC.
Small capacitors (e.g., 100nF, 1nF, 4.7uF) connected from UIM1_VCC to ground to filter noise and ensure stable voltage supply.
A device (e.g., a diode array like DALC208SC6) connected between UIM1_VCC and ground to protect the module and SIM card from electrostatic discharge.

implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to the VCC pin of the UIM1 card holder or socket. It is also recommended to connect a decoupling capacitor (typically 100nF and 1nF in parallel) and a 4.7uF capacitor from this pin to ground, placed as close as possible to the UIM card connector. ESD protection is also recommended for this pin.
implementation.detailed_description: UIM1_VCC is an output pin that provides a regulated voltage supply to the UIM1 interface, which is used to power the SIM card. It supports both 1.8V and 2.85V UIM cards, allowing for compatibility with different SIM card standards.
implementation.functionality: The primary function is to supply power to the UIM1 interface. The voltage level (1.8V or 2.85V) is selectable based on the SIM card type or configuration. In cases where the UIM1 interface is not used, this pin should be left open.
precautions: Ensure the correct voltage level (1.8V or 2.85V) is supported or configured for the connected SIM card.
Place decoupling capacitors and ESD protection components as close as possible to the UIM card connector to maximize their effectiveness.
If the UIM1 interface is not used, this pin must be left open to prevent potential issues.
Refer to the UIM interface schematic in Figure 5-8 for a detailed implementation example.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect directly to the UIM2_CLK pin of the UIM2 interface or eSIM component. Ensure that the voltage level (1.8V or 2.85V) is compatible with the chosen UIM/eSIM.

implementation.connectivity: The UIM2_CLK pin should be connected to the corresponding UIM2_CLK pin on the UIM2 interface or the eSIM component. For standard operation, the pin should be connected directly. If the UIM2 interface is unused, the pin should be left open.
implementation.detailed_description: The UIM2_CLK pin is an output signal from the module that provides the clock signal for the second Universal Subscriber Identity Module (UIM) interface. This clock signal is essential for the UIM card's operation, synchronizing data transfer between the module and the UIM.
implementation.functionality: This pin is primarily used as UIM2_CLK for the second UIM interface. However, in specific limited availability variants (RC7612 and RC7612-1), this pin is also designated as a 'Core' type, indicating its essential role for basic module functionality. It is also noted that the pin can be 'wakeable,' meaning it can be used to trigger the module to wake up from a sleep state.
precautions: For RC7611, RC7620, RC7630, and RC7630J* variants, UIM2 signals (including UIM2_CLK) are not available externally, as this interface is used for an eSIM. Ensure the correct variant is being used if external UIM2 connectivity is required.
The UIM2_CLK pin operates at either 1.8V or 2.85V. Ensure the connected UIM/eSIM component supports the chosen voltage level.
If the UIM2 interface is not used, the pin should be left open to avoid any potential issues.

While the pin is marked as 'wakeable', its use for waking the module from sleep state requires specific firmware configuration. Consult the RC76xx AT Command Reference for details on enabling this functionality.

connected_components.connection_details: Connects to the DATA pin of the UIM connector or the eSIM module.
connected_components.notes: Only applicable for RC7612 and RC7612-1 variants.

implementation.connectivity: In the RC7612 and RC7612-1 variants, UIM2_DATA connects to the DATA pin of the second UIM connector or eSIM. For other variants where it's associated with an eSIM, it's internally connected and not exposed externally.
implementation.detailed_description: UIM2_DATA is the data interface pin for the second Universal Integrated Circuit (UIM) interface. This pin handles the bidirectional communication of data between the module and the UIM card or eSIM.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of UIM2_DATA is to transmit and receive data for the second UIM interface. For RC7611, RC7620, RC7630, and RC7630J* variants, this pin is associated with an eSIM and is not externally available. For RC7612 and RC7612-1 (Limited Availability) variants, this pin is available for an external UIM card.
precautions: For RC7611, RC7620, RC7630, and RC7630J* variants, this pin is associated with an eSIM and is not available externally. Do not attempt to connect external components to it.
UIM1 and UIM2 cannot be activated simultaneously. Ensure proper SIM selection is configured via AT commands.
The UIM interface signals, including UIM2_DATA, must be ESD protected if exposed externally.

connected_components.details: Connects to the RESET pin of the UIM2 interface. The module provides the reset signal to this pin. For RC7612/RC7612-1, this would be an external UIM connector. For other variants, it controls an eSIM on the module.

implementation.connectivity: The UIM2_RESET_N pin should be connected to the RESET pin of the UIM2 interface (either an external UIM connector or an eSIM). The connection should be a direct wire from the module's UIM2_RESET_N pin to the UIM2 interface's RESET pin.
implementation.detailed_description: UIM2_RESET_N is an output signal from the module that provides a reset signal to the UIM2 interface. This signal is used to reset the UIM2 interface, which can be an external UIM or an eSIM, during the power-up sequence or during normal operation if a reset is required.
implementation.functionality: The UIM2_RESET_N signal's primary function is to reset the UIM2 interface. Its functionality depends on whether it is connected to an external UIM or an eSIM. For RC7612 and RC7612-1, it interfaces with an external UIM2. For other variants (RC7611, RC7620, RC7630, and RC7630J*), it controls an eSIM. The specific behavior (e.g., timing, voltage levels) might be dictated by the UIM/eSIM standard and the module's firmware.
precautions: Ensure the voltage level of UIM2_RESET_N is compatible with the UIM2 interface (1.8V or 2.85V).
Follow the timing requirements for the UIM reset signal as specified by the UIM/eSIM standard and the module's documentation.
Do not connect any external pull-up resistors to this pin, as the module manages the signal's state internally.
The pin's functionality and availability might vary between module variants (e.g., RC7612/RC7612-1 vs. other variants). Refer to the specific variant's documentation.
If the UIM2 interface is not used, this pin can be left open as per the datasheet's 'If Unused' column.

connected_components.component_name: UIM2 Interface (eSIM or External UIM Connector)
connected_components.connection_details: Connects to the VCC pin of the UIM2 interface.
Provides the 1.8V or 2.85V supply voltage to the UIM2_VCC pin, selectable based on the UIM card/eSIM requirement.

implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to the VCC (power supply) pin of the UIM2 interface, whether it's an eSIM or an external UIM card connector. The voltage level is selectable (1.8V or 2.85V) based on the UIM card or eSIM. If the UIM2 interface is not used, this pin should be left open.
implementation.detailed_description: UIM2_VCC is an output pin that supplies power to the second UIM interface (UIM2). The voltage provided is either 1.8V or 2.85V, depending on the UIM card's requirements. This pin is part of the module's UIM interface functionality.
implementation.functionality: This pin serves as a power supply output for the UIM2 interface. For specific variants (RC7611, RC7620, RC7630, and RC7630J*), this interface is associated with an eSIM. For RC7612 and RC7612-1 variants (Limited Availability), it is an external UIM2 interface. The pin is powered down when UIM2 is deselected.
precautions: Ensure that the correct voltage (1.8V or 2.85V) is provided to the UIM2_VCC pin based on the UIM card or eSIM being used. Incorrect voltage can lead to damage.
If the UIM2 interface is not used, leave the UIM2_VCC pin unconnected to prevent potential issues.
The UIM2 interface cannot be activated simultaneously with the UIM1 interface. Ensure proper SIM selection logic is implemented.
Refer to the RC76xx AT Command Reference for details on managing SIM selection and power states of the UIM2 interface.

connected_components.description: The external USB connector on the host device. The USB_D+ pin of the module connects to the corresponding USB_D+ pin on this connector.
The internal pin on the RC76xx module that is part of the USB interface.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the USB_D+ pin of the host USB connector. It should also be connected to the USB_D+ pin of the module.
implementation.detailed_description: USB_D+ is the positive data line for the high-speed USB 2.0 interface. It is part of the differential data pair (USB_D+ and USB_D-) used for communication.
implementation.functionality: The pin serves as a bidirectional data line for USB 2.0 communication. It operates as part of a differential signaling pair to ensure robust data transfer.
precautions: The USB interface has routing constraints. Refer to Section 5.7.4 'USB Interface' for details.
It is recommended to make the USB interface accessible through test points for debugging.
ESD protection is required on the USB_D+ line, as well as USB_D- and USB_VBUS.
Differential data pair matching should be within 3.8 mm (150 mils).
Avoid having multiple vias on the USB traces as they can cause signal reflection.
Avoid stubs on the USB traces.
Test points on USB traces must comply with radio frequency signal routing rules to avoid degradation of USB signal quality.
The USB_VBUS trace width should be sized appropriately for the expected current and length.

connected_components.connection_details: Direct connection to the USB_D- pin of the host.
Recommended to have ESD protection on this pin, connected between the pin and ground, typically a diode array.

implementation.connectivity: In a schematic, USB_D- should be connected to the corresponding USB_D- pin of the host USB connector or controller. It is part of a differential pair and should be routed with its complementary signal (USB_D+) to maintain signal integrity.
implementation.detailed_description: USB_D- is the negative differential data line for the High-Speed USB 2.0 interface. It is part of the differential pair (USB_D+ and USB_D-) used for high-speed data communication.
implementation.functionality: The pin serves as a bidirectional data line for USB communication. Its function is solely related to the USB 2.0 High-Speed interface.
precautions: Route as a differential pair with USB_D+ for optimal signal integrity, maintaining controlled impedance (90 Ω differential) and matching trace lengths.
Keep the traces away from sensitive circuits and signals (RF, system clock) to prevent interference.
Minimize the number of vias to reduce signal reflection and impedance discontinuities.
Avoid stubs on these traces.
Ensure proper ESD protection is implemented on this pin.

connected_components.details: Provides a stable DC voltage within the specified operating range (3.2V to 4.3V) for the VBAT_BB pin. This can be a battery, a voltage regulator, or a power management IC.

Decoupling capacitors (e.g., 47 µF) should be placed close to the VBAT_BB pin to filter noise and handle current peaks, as described in the 'Power Supply' and 'Routing Constraints and Recommendations' sections.

implementation.connectivity: VBAT_BB should be connected to a regulated DC power supply. It can be connected either as a single supply to both VBAT_BB and VBAT_RF, or as separate supplies for each. The voltage range must be maintained between 3.2V and 4.3V (nominal 3.7V).
implementation.detailed_description: VBAT_BB is the power supply input for the Baseband section of the Semtech RC76xx module. It requires a regulated DC voltage within a specified range to operate correctly.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of VBAT_BB is to supply power to the baseband processing unit of the module. It can be connected as a single regulated DC power supply or as one of two regulated DC power supplies, with VBAT_RF being the other.
precautions: The voltage applied to VBAT_BB must strictly remain within the specified operating range (3.2V to 4.3V). Exceeding the maximum specified operating voltage can damage the module.
Ensure the power supply has sufficient current capability to handle the peak current demands of the baseband processor, especially during high-load operations.
Minimize voltage ripple and transients on the VBAT_BB supply line. Refer to Table 3-3 for specific ripple and transient voltage limits.
Proper decoupling is essential to maintain stable operation and prevent noise coupling. Place decoupling capacitors as close as possible to the module's VBAT_BB pin.
The impedance of the power supply and power delivery network should be kept as low as possible to reduce voltage drop during current peaks.

connected_components.details: A regulated DC power supply with a nominal voltage of 3.7V. The supply must be capable of delivering the required current for the RF components, especially during transmission. The power supply voltage must be within the specified operating range (3.2V to 4.3V) and should have low ripple and transients.

Decoupling capacitors should be placed as close as possible to the VBAT_RF pins to filter noise and ensure stable power delivery. Typically, this would include larger bulk capacitors (e.g., 10-47 µF) and smaller ceramic capacitors (e.g., 10-33 pF).

implementation.connectivity: VBAT_RF should be connected to a regulated DC power supply. It can be connected to a single regulated DC power supply (3.7V nominal) shared with VBAT_BB, or to a separate regulated DC power supply (3.7V nominal) dedicated to the RF components.
implementation.detailed_description: VBAT_RF is the RF power supply input pin for the Semtech RC76xx module. It is responsible for providing the necessary power to the radio frequency components of the module.
implementation.functionality: The pin serves as a power supply input for the RF section. It can be used as a single supply for both VBAT_BB and VBAT_RF, or as a separate supply for VBAT_RF.
precautions: The voltage applied to VBAT_RF must be within the specified operating range (3.2V to 4.3V). Exceeding this range can damage the module's RF components.
The power supply must have low ripple and transients, as specified in the datasheet (e.g., power supply ripple < 100 mVpp).
Ensure the power supply and its traces can deliver the peak currents required by the RF components during transmission.
Adequate decoupling capacitors must be placed close to the VBAT_RF pins to ensure stable operation and prevent noise coupling.
If VBAT_BB and VBAT_RF are supplied separately, ensure their voltage levels are within their respective operating ranges.

connected_components.description: Components requiring a 1.8V logic supply, such as pull-up resistors for I/O pins, LEDs, or other digital components.
The VGPIO pin can be used as a voltage reference for the module's ADC inputs.
If the current draw from VGPIO exceeds its capability, an external voltage regulator can be used to provide a higher current supply.

implementation.connectivity: The VGPIO pin should be connected to external circuitry that requires a 1.8V logic level supply. If a higher current is needed than what VGPIO can supply, an external regulator should be used to step up the voltage.
implementation.detailed_description: The VGPIO pin serves as a 1.8V logic voltage output from the Semtech RC76xx module. This voltage is provided when the module is powered ON and is used to supply external circuitry, pull up I/Os, or act as a voltage reference for ADC interfaces.
implementation.functionality: The VGPIO pin provides a stable 1.8V output. Its functionality is primarily to supply power to external digital components. It is also used as a reference voltage for ADC inputs. The VGPIO is active (1.8V) when the module is in active or sleep mode and is off (high impedance) when the module is in PSM or off mode.
precautions: The VGPIO output current capability is limited to 50 mA. Do not exceed this limit; use an external regulator if higher current is required.
VGPIO is off (high impedance) when the module is in PSM or off mode. Ensure that external circuitry connected to VGPIO handles this state appropriately.
Ensure that signals referenced to VGPIO are properly managed when the module transitions between power states to avoid unexpected behavior or damage.

WAKE_ON_WWAN.description:
Driven high to wake
the host when
specific events
occur.

connected_components.description: An input pin on the host microcontroller or system that can detect a logic high signal. This pin will be used to trigger an interrupt or polling mechanism on the host to handle the event indicated by WAKE_ON_WWAN.

A resistor connected between the host input pin and the host's VGPIO (or equivalent logic supply) to ensure a defined logic high state when the WAKE_ON_WWAN signal is active. The value of this resistor should be chosen based on the host's input impedance and desired signal rise time, typically in the range of 10 kΩ to 100 kΩ.

implementation.connectivity: The WAKE_ON_WWAN pin should be connected to a suitable input on the host device that can detect a logic high signal. A recommended implementation involves a pull-up resistor on the host side, with the module's WAKE_ON_WWAN pin connected to this pull-up. The specific value of the pull-up resistor would depend on the host's input characteristics and general schematic design practices.
implementation.detailed_description: The WAKE_ON_WWAN pin is a digital output signal from the Semtech RC76xx module that is designed to wake up a host device when specific events occur within the module. These events include, but are not limited to, an incoming SMS message or incoming data packets.
implementation.functionality: The pin's functionality is to signal the host device that an event requiring attention has occurred. This can be configured by the host using the AT!CUSTOM command with the WAKEHOSTEN option. When configured, the module drives this pin high to initiate the wake-up sequence for the host. The specific events that trigger this signal depend on firmware settings and host driver configurations (e.g., QMI event registration for incoming data packets).
precautions: Host support for the WAKE_ON_WWAN signal is optional. If the host does not require this functionality, the pin can be left unconnected.
The functionality of the WAKE_ON_WWAN pin can be configured using AT commands (AT!CUSTOM with WAKEHOSTEN option). Ensure this is correctly configured based on the intended application.
For Linux Host systems, enabling WDS event reporting in the SDK application is crucial for the WAKE_ON_WWAN pin to be triggered by incoming data packets.
Ensure proper impedance matching and signal integrity for the connection between the module and the host device.

WAKE_ON_WWAN.name: WAKE_ON_WWAN

connected_components.details: A Light Emitting Diode that visually indicates WWAN status.
A resistor is required to limit the current flowing through the LED to prevent damage. The value of the resistor will depend on the forward voltage of the LED and the supply voltage (VGPIO).
The 1.8V GPIO voltage output from the module, which provides the necessary supply voltage for the LED circuit.

implementation.connectivity: The WWAN_LED_N pin should be connected to the anode of an external LED. The cathode of the LED should be connected to a current-limiting resistor, which is then connected to the module's VGPIO supply. Alternatively, if the LED is designed to be driven directly from the module, the WWAN_LED_N pin can be connected to the cathode of an LED, with the anode connected to the current-limiting resistor and then to VGPIO.
implementation.detailed_description: The WWAN_LED_N pin is an output signal from the Semtech RC76xx module that serves as an LED driver control.
implementation.functionality: This pin is used to control an external LED, typically to indicate WWAN activity or status. It acts as a sink for current, allowing an external LED to be driven when the pin is pulled low by the module.
implementation.precautions: The WWAN_LED_N pin has a maximum current sink capability of 40 mA. Ensure that the current-limiting resistor is correctly chosen to stay within this limit and to prevent damage to the LED or the module. The voltage on this pin will be approximately VGPIO (1.8V) when not active and can source current when pulled low. If connecting an LED directly, ensure the LED's forward voltage is compatible with the VGPIO supply.

implementation.connected_components: The W_DISABLE_N pin is typically connected to a general-purpose output (GPO) or a similar control pin on the host microcontroller or system. The host's GPIO should be configured to drive this pin low when radio disable is required and to enter a high-impedance or floating state otherwise. No external pull-up resistor is needed as one is provided internally by the module.
implementation.connectivity: This pin should be connected to a host device's control signal. The host device controls the state of this pin. It is recommended to leave this signal unconnected if the host device does not need to control the module's radio state. The pin has an internal pull-up resistor to an internal 1.8V rail.
implementation.detailed_description: The W_DISABLE_N pin is an input to the module that is used by the host device to enable or disable the WWAN radio (modem). When this signal is asserted (driven low), the modem cannot transmit or receive information. When the signal is de-asserted (floating or high impedance), the radio operates normally.
implementation.functionality: The primary function is to control the power state of the WWAN radio. It acts as a digital input. When driven low, it disables the radio; when floating or high impedance, it allows the radio to operate normally. It is an input to the module and is intended for host control.
implementation.precautions: The host should drive this pin LOW only for its active state (disabling the radio). It should never be driven to a logic high level by the host. If the host never needs to assert this power state control to the module, leaving the signal unconnected is acceptable. Ensure the host's output is capable of driving the pin low and entering a high-impedance state. Avoid connecting this pin to any other components or signals without careful consideration of the internal pull-up and the intended functionality.
